PART 1: FISCAL AFFAIRS
Section
   
1-101   Compensation of Mayor
   
1-102   Compensation of Borough Council
§ 1-101 COMPENSATION OF MAYOR.
   Compensation to be paid to the Mayor shall be set by Borough Council in the
amount of $l,200 per year, to be paid in quarterly installments at the end of
each quarter for performance of the duties imposed by the Borough Code. Any
Mayor who shall not serve in such capacity for a full calendar quarter shall be
paid on a pro-rated basis of one-third of the quarterly salary for each month
he or she has served in the capacity of Mayor.
(Ord. 2000-4, passed 8-8-2000, § 1; Ord. 2007-1, passed 1-9-2007)
§ 1-102 COMPENSATION OF BOROUGH COUNCIL.
   Compensation to be paid to members of the Borough Council shall be set by
Borough Council in the amount of $1,200 per year, to be paid in quarterly
installments for performance of the duties imposed by the Borough Code. Any
Council member who shall not serve in such capacity for a full calendar quarter
shall be paid on a pro-rated basis of one-third of the quarterly salary for
each month he or she has served in the capacity of Council member.
(Ord. 2000-4, passed 8-8-2000, § 2; Ord. 2007-1, passed 1-9-2007)
PART 2: BOROUGH MANAGER
Section
   
1-201   Creation of office of Borough Manager
   
1-202   Duties and responsibilities
   
1-203   General Purchasing Agent
   
1-204   Budget
   
1-205   Municipal records
   
1-206   Execution of contracts
   
1-207   Appointment of Borough Manager
   
1-208   Absence of Borough Manager
§ 1-201 CREATION OF OFFICE OF BOROUGH MANAGER.
   There is hereby created in the borough the office of the Borough Manager of
the Borough of Dillsburg.
(Ord. 1988-4, passed 11-15-1988, § 8001; Ord. 2003-2, passed 10-8-2003; Ord.
2005-1, passed 2-8-2005)
§ 1-202 DUTIES AND RESPONSIBILITIES.
   The job description may be updated by Council and revised from time to time
as duties and responsibilities of the position change, as skills and abilities
of the Borough Manager change or as new duties and responsibilities of the
Borough Manager are identified. The job description shall be referred to and
maintained in the Employee Handbook.
(Ord. 1988-4, passed 11-15-1988, § 8002; Ord. 2003-2, passed 10-8-2003; Ord.
2005-1, passed 2-8-2005)
§ 1-203 GENERAL PURCHASING AGENT.
   The Borough Manager shall be the general purchasing agent for the borough,
and, except where specific provision to the contrary is made by law or by
Council, he or she shall make all purchases of supplies, materials and
equipment required to facilitate operation of the borough, including the water
system, and sewage system, subject to limitations imposed by law, provided that
he or she secure prior approval of Council for purchases of products or
materials at a cost in excess of $500.
(Ord. 1988-4, passed 11-15-1988, § 8003 Ord. 2003-2, passed 10-8-2003; Ord.
2005-1, passed 2-8-2005)
§ 1-204 BUDGET.
   The Borough Manager shall assist the Finance Committee in the preparation of
the budget for the ensuing year and in the preparation of the annual
appropriation ordinance. The Borough Manager shall also review the accounts of
the Borough Treasurer and report upon the fiscal condition, including current
and anticipated expenses, appropriations, cash on hand and anticipated revenues
from all funds and accounts, and provide a report at each Borough Council
meeting, as required by Council.
(Ord. 1988-4, passed 11-15-1988, § 8004 Ord. 2003-2, passed 10-8-2003; Ord.
2005-1, passed 2-8-2005)
§ 1-205 MUNICIPAL RECORDS.
   The Borough Manager shall maintain the custody and safeguarding of all
municipal records which are maintained as required by law, or by mandate of
Council.
(Ord. 1988-4, passed 11-15-1988, § 8005 Ord. 2003-2, passed 10-8-2003; Ord.
2005-1, passed 2-8-2005)
§ 1-206 EXECUTION OF CONTRACTS.
   The Borough Manager shall not be authorized to execute contracts obligating
the borough at any time unless execution of those contracts is authorized by
ordinance or resolution of the Borough Council.
(Ord. 1988-4, passed 11-15-1988, § 8009 Ord. 2003-2, passed 10-8-2003; Ord.
2005-1, passed 2-8-2005)
§ 1-207 APPOINTMENT OF BOROUGH MANAGER.
   The Borough Manager shall be appointed by resolution of Council.
(Ord. 1988-4, passed 11-15-1988, § 8010 Ord. 2003-2, passed 10-8-2003; Ord.
2005-1, passed 2-8-2005)
§ 1-208 ABSENCE OF BOROUGH MANAGER.
   If at any time the Borough Manager shall be absent from the borough, or
incapacitated and prevented from performing duties of the position, the
President of Council shall perform such duties until such time as a special
meeting of the Council can be held, at which time Council shall determine
whether another qualified person shall operate as Borough Manager during the
absence or incapacity.
(Ord. 1988-4, passed 11-15-1988, § 8011 Ord. 2003-2, passed 10-8-2003; by Ord.
2005-1, passed 2-8-2005)
PART 3: RESERVED
Editor’s note:
   Chapter 1, Part 3 previously contained provisions for the Borough Secretary
Treasurer. In Ordinance 2011-7, passed December 13, 2011, the Borough Council
created two distinct and separate positions, one for the Secretary and one for
the Treasurer, as allowed by state statute.
    Complete job descriptions of each position were created and are maintained
in the Employee Handbook.
PART 4: PLANNING COMMISSION
Section
   
1-401   Establishment of Planning Commission
   
1-402   Meetings
   
1-403   Duties of Planning Commission
   
1-404   Powers of Planning Commission
§ 1-401 ESTABLISHMENT OF PLANNING COMMISSION.
   (A)   There is hereby established for the borough a Planning Commission to
consist of five members to be appointed by Council. All members shall be
residents of the borough and at least three members shall not hold office or be
employees of the borough.
   (B)   Council shall appoint original members to the Planning Commission for
terms effective January 1, 1986, as follows:
      (1)   Two members shall be appointed for terms of two years;
      (2)   Two members shall be appointed for terms of three years; and
      (3)   One member shall be appointed for a term of four years.
   (C)   As each of the original terms shall expire, members shall be appointed
for terms of four years.
   (D)   Whenever a vacancy occurs on the Commission, the Chairperson of the
Planning Commission shall promptly notify Council who will then appoint another
member to fill the unexpired term of the vacant officer.
(Ord. 1985-5, passed 12-17-1985, § 1)
§ 1-402 MEETINGS.
   (A)   The Planning Commission shall meet monthly and hold such other
meetings as may be necessary to fulfill its duties and obligations imposed in
the following sections.
   (B)   The Commission shall conduct its business in accordance with § 207 of
the Municipalities Planning Code, being 53 P.S. §§ 10101 et seq.
   (C)   A quorum for any meeting shall be a majority of members appointed then
holding office, and action shall be taken on the vote of a majority of the
members present at the meeting.
(Ord. 1985-5, passed 12-17-1985, § 2)
§ 1-403 DUTIES OF PLANNING COMMISSION.
   The Planning Commission shall have the following duties:
   (A)   To develop and maintain the comprehensive plan for the development of
the borough in accordance with the requirements of §§ 301 through 306 of the
Pennsylvania Municipalities Planning Code, as may be amended from time to time;
   (B)   The Planning Commission shall maintain and keep on file records of all
its actions;
   (C)   The Planning Commission shall, from time to time, as it deems
advisable, recommend amendments to the subdivision and land development
ordinance (
Chapter 22 of this code of ordinances) as well as the zoning ordinance (
Chapter 27 of this code of ordinances);
   (D)   The Planning Commission shall review all plans submitted for any
subdivision, land development or planned residential development and make
recommendations to Council for their approval or disapproval within an
appropriate time for Council to take action in accordance with the Pennsylvania
Municipalities Planning Code;
   (E)   At the request of Council, the Planning Commission shall review and
make recommendations for the following:
      (1)   Any recommendations concerning amendment of the official map;
      (2)   Recommendations for the development and adoption of a building and
housing code including recommendations for proposed amendments thereto if
adopted;
      (3)   Preparation and presentation to Council of an environmental study
with respect to actions contemplated by Council or developers; and
      (4)   Recommendations with respect to any governmental, civic and private
agencies and individuals as to effectiveness of the proposals of such agencies
and individuals.
(Ord. 1985-5, passed 12-17-1985, § 3)
§ 1-404 POWERS OF PLANNING COMMISSION.
   The Planning Commission shall have the following powers:
   (A)   To promote interest and understanding of the comprehensive plan and
planning;
   (B)   To hold public hearings and meetings in furtherance of its obligations
and responsibilities;
   (C)   Require from any department or agency of the borough or the Dillsburg
Area Authority to make available such information as may relate to the work of
the Planning Commission;
   (D)   Enter upon any land with the consent of the owner to make examinations
and surveys in the performance of its duties;
   (E)   Do such other act or make such other studies as may be necessary to
fulfill the duties and obligations of the Planning Commission in accordance
with this Part and other governmental regulations; and
   (F)   With approval of Council, to make expenditures for expert assistance
as may be required including, but not limited to, expertise in engineering,
legal advice, financial advice or such other expertise as may be required to
fulfill the functions of the Planning Commission.
(Ord. 1985-5, passed 12-17-1985, § 3)
PART 5: FIRE INSURANCE ESCROW
Section
   
1-501   Designated officer
   
1-502   Payment of claim
   
1-503   Insurance proceeds
   
1-504   Procedures and regulations
   
1-505   Penalty
§ 1-501 DESIGNATED OFFICER.
   The Manager of the borough or such official’s designee is hereby appointed
as the designated officer who is authorized to carry out all responsibilities
and duties stated herein.
(Ord. 1999-07, passed 9-14-1999, § 1)
§ 1-502 PAYMENT OF CLAIM.
   No insurance company, association or exchange (hereinafter the “insuring
agent”) doing business in the Commonwealth shall pay a claim of a named insured
for fire damage to a structure located within the borough (hereinafter the
“municipality”) where the amount recoverable for the fire loss to the structure
under all policies exceeds $7,500, unless the insuring agent is, upon request
of the insuring agent, furnished by the Borough Treasurer with a municipal
certificate pursuant to Act 98 of 1992, as amended, and unless there is
compliance with § 508(b), (c) and (d) of said Act, as amended, and the
provisions of this Part.
(Ord. 1999-07, passed 9-14-1999, § 2)
§ 1-503 INSURANCE PROCEEDS.
   Where, pursuant to § 508(b)(1)(I) and other provisions of Act 98 of 1992, as
amended, the Borough Treasurer issues a certificate indicating that there are
no delinquent taxes, assessments, penalties or user charges against real
property or costs incurred or estimated by the borough for the removal, repair
or securing of a building or other structure on the property, the insuring
agent shall pay the claim of the named insured, provided however, that if the
loss agreed upon by the named insured and the insuring agent equals or exceeds
60% of the aggregate limits of liability on all fire policies covering the
building restructure, the following procedures must be followed.
   (A)   The insuring agent shall transfer from the insurance proceeds to the
designated officer of the borough in the aggregate of $2,000 for each $15,000
of a claim and for each fraction of that amount of a claim, this section to be
applied such that if the claim is $15,000 or less, the maximum amount
transferred to the borough shall be $2,000.
   (B)   If at the time of a proof of loss agreed to between the named insured
and the insuring agent, the named insured has submitted a contractor’s signed
estimate of the costs of removing, repairing or securing the building or other
structure in an amount less than the amount calculated under the foregoing
transfer formula set forth in subsection (A) above, the insuring agent shall
transfer to the borough from the insurance proceeds the amount specified in the
estimate.
   (C)   The transfer of proceeds shall be on pro rata basis by all insuring
agents insuring the building or other structure.
   (D)   After the transfer, the named insured may submit a contractor’s signed
estimate of the costs of removing, repairing or securing the building or other
structure, and the designated officer shall return the amount of the funds
transferred to the borough in excess of the estimate and in excess of the
amount of delinquent taxes, assessments, penalties or user charges, to the
named insured, if the borough has not commenced to remove, repair or secure the
building or other structure.
   (E)   Upon receipt of proceeds under this section, the borough shall do the
following:
      (1)   The designated officer shall place the proceeds in a separate fund
to be used solely as security against the total costs of removing, repairing or
securing the building or structure which are incurred by the borough as well as
payment of the amount of delinquent taxes, assessments, penalties or user
charges. Such costs shall include, without limitation, any engineering, legal
or administrative costs incurred by the borough in connection with such
removal, repair or securing of the building or any proceedings related thereto;
      (2)   It is the obligation of the insuring agent when transferring the
proceeds to provide the borough with the name and address of the named insured.
Upon receipt of the transferred funds and the name and address of the named
insured, the designated officer shall contact the named insured, certify that
the proceeds have been received by the borough and notify the named insured
that the procedures under this subsection (E) shall be followed;
      (3)   When repairs, removal or securing of the building or other
structure have been corrected in accordance with all applicable regulations and
orders of the borough and the required proof of such completion received by the
designated officer, and if the borough has not incurred any costs for repairs,
removal or securing and if there are no outstanding delinquent taxes,
assessments, penalties or user charges, the fund shall be returned to the named
insured. If the borough has incurred costs for repairs, removal or securing of
the building or other structure, the costs shall be paid from the fund and if
excess funds remain after payment of outstanding delinquent taxes, assessments,
penalties or user charges, the borough shall transfer the remaining funds to
the named insured; and
      (4)   To the extent interest is earned on proceeds held by the borough
pursuant to this section, and not returned to the named insured, such interest
shall belong to the borough. To the extent that proceeds are returned to the
named insured, interest earned on such proceeds shall be distributed to the
named insured at the time that the proceeds are returned.
   (F)   Nothing in this section shall be construed to limit the ability of the
borough to recover any deficiency. Furthermore, nothing in this section shall
be construed to prohibit the borough and the named insured from entering into
an agreement that permits the transfer of funds to the named insured of some
other reasonable disposition of the damaged property has been negotiated.
(Ord. 1999-07, passed 9-14-1999, § 3)
§ 1-504 PROCEDURES AND REGULATIONS.
   The Borough Council may, by resolution, adopt procedures and regulations to
implement Act 98 of 1992, as amended, and to fix reasonable fees to be charged
for municipal activities or services provided pursuant to Act 98 of 1992, as
amended, and by this Part; including but not limited to, issuance of
certificates and bills, performance of inspections and opening separate fund
accounts.
(Ord. 1999-07, passed 9-14-1999, § 4)
§ 1-505 PENALTY.
   Any owner of property, any named insured or any insurance agent, or any
person, firm, corporation or other entity, who shall violate any provision of
this part shall, upon conviction thereof, be sentenced to pay a fine of not
more than $1,000 plus costs and, in default of payment of said fine and costs
to a term of imprisonment not to exceed 30 days. Each day that a violation of
this part continues or each section of this Part which shall be found to have
been violated shall constitute a separate offense.
(Ord. 1999-07, passed 9-14-1999, § 5)
PART 6: OPEN RECORDS POLICY
Section
   
1-601   General rule
   
1-602   Request for access to public records
   
1-603   Borough’s response to requests for access
   
1-604   Redaction
   
1-605   Final borough determination
   
1-606   Judicial appeal
   
1-607   Fees
   
1-608   Borough contact
   
1-609   Regular business hours
   
1-610   Person designated to accept exceptions filed when a record is denied
   
1-611   Miscellaneous
§ 1-601 GENERAL RULE.
   (A)   Unless otherwise prohibited by law, the borough shall make all public
records, as defined by the Pennsylvania Open Records Law, accessible for
inspection and duplication by a requestor in accordance with 65 P.S. §§ 67.101
et seq.
   (B)   A public record shall be provided to a requestor in the medium
requested if the public record exists in that medium; otherwise, it shall be
provided in the medium in which it exists, except for the provision in §
1-611(B).
   (C)   Public records shall be available for access during the regular
business hours of the borough. Nothing in this Part shall provide for access to
a record which is not a public record.
§ 1-602 REQUEST FOR ACCESS TO PUBLIC RECORDS.
   (A)   (1)   All requests for public records shall be in writing and shall be
set forth on the borough request form.
      (2)   The form shall include, among other things, the requestor’s contact
information, date received and specific records requested. Requests may be
submitted in person or by mail or fax.
   (B)   Requests must be specific enough for the borough to determine what
records are needed.
§ 1-603 BOROUGH’S RESPONSE TO REQUESTS FOR ACCESS.
   (A)   General rule. Upon receipt of a written request for access to a
record, the borough shall make a good faith effort to determine if the record
requested is a public record and to respond as promptly as possible under the
circumstances existing at the time of the request, but shall not exceed five
business days from the date the written request is received by the borough.
Except as set forth in subsection (B) below, if the borough fails to send the
response within five business days of receipt of the written request for
access, the written request for access shall be deemed denied.
   (B)   Exception.
      (1)   Upon receipt of a written request for access, if the borough
determines that one of the following applies:
         (a)   The request for access request requires redaction of a public
record;
         (b)   The request for access requires the retrieval of a record stored
in a remote location.
         (c)   A timely response to the request for access cannot be
accomplished due to bona fide and specific staffing limitations;
         (d)   A legal review is necessary to determine whether the record is a
public record subject to access under 65 P.S. §§ 67.101 et seq.;
         (e)   The requestor has not complied with the borough’s policy
regarding access to public records;
         (f)   The requestor refuses to pay applicable fee set forth in this
Part.
      (2)   Then the borough shall send written notice to the requestor within
five business days of the borough’s receipt of the request notifying the
requestor that the request for access is being reviewed, the reason for the
review and a reasonable date that a response is expected to be provided. If the
date that a response is expected to be provided is in excess of 30 days,
following the five business days allowed under subsection (A) above, the
request for access shall be deemed denied.
   (C)   Denial. If the borough’s response is a denial of a written request for
access, whether in whole or in part, a written response shall be issued and
include:
      (1)   A description of the record requested;
      (2)   The specific reasons for the denial, including a citation of
supporting legal authority. If the denial is the result of a determination that
the record requested is not a public record, the specific reasons for the
borough’s determination that the record is not a public record shall be
included;
      (3)   The typed or printed name, title, business address, business
telephone number and signature of the public official or public employee on
whose authority the denial is issued;
      (4)   Date of the response; and
      (5)   The procedure to appeal the denial of access under 65 P.S. §§ 66.1
et seq.
§ 1-604 REDACTION.
   If the borough determines that a public record contains information which is
subject to access, as well as information which is not subject to access, the
borough’s response shall grant access to the information which is subject to
access and deny access to the information which is not subject to access. If
the information which is not subject to access is an integral part of the
public record and cannot be separated, the borough shall redact from the public
record the information which is not subject to access and the response shall
grant access to the information which is subject to access. The borough may not
deny access to the public record if the information which is not subject to
public access is able to be redacted. Information which the borough redacts in
accordance with this section shall be deemed a denial under §
1-603(C) of this Part.
§ 1-605 FINAL BOROUGH DETERMINATION.
   (A)   Filing of exceptions. If a written request for access is denied or
deemed denied, the requestor may file exceptions with the Borough Manager/
Secretary of the borough within 15 business days of the mailing date of the
borough’s response or within 15 days of a deemed denial. The exceptions shall
state grounds upon which the requestor asserts that the record is a public
record and shall address any grounds stated by the borough for delaying or
denying the request.
   (B)   Determination. Unless the requestor agrees otherwise, the Borough
Manager/Secretary or his or her designee shall make a final determination
regarding the exceptions within 30 days of the mailing date of the exceptions.
Prior to issuing the final determination regarding the exceptions, the Borough
Manager/Secretary or his or her designee may conduct a hearing. The
determination shall be the final order of the borough. If the Borough Manager/
Secretary or his or her designee determines that the borough correctly denied
the request for access, the Manager/Secretary or his or her designee shall
provide a written explanation to the requestor of the reason for the denial.
§ 1-606 JUDICIAL APPEAL.
   (A)   Filing a petition. Within 30 days of the denial by the borough
pursuant to §
1-603(C) of this Part, or of the mailing date of a final determination of the
borough affirming the denial of access, a requestor may file a petition for
review or other document as might be required by Rule of Court with the Court
of Common Pleas of York County or bring an action in the local magisterial
district. A requestor is entitled to a reasoned decision containing findings of
fact and conclusions of law based upon the evidence as a whole which clearly
and concisely states and explains the rationale for the decisions so that all
can determine why and how a particular result was reached.
   (B)   Notice. The borough shall be served notice of actions commenced in
accordance with subsection (A) above and shall have an opportunity to respond
in accordance with applicable court rules.
§ 1-607 FEES.
   (A)   Fees generally. The borough may charge the following fees for requests
made for access to public records:
      (1)   Postage. Fees for postage shall be the actual cost of mailing;
      (2)   Copying. Fees for duplication by photocopying, printing from
electronic media or microfilm, copying onto electronic media, transmission by
facsimile or other electronic means and other means of duplication shall be the
same as the per copy fee set forth in the borough’s fee schedule, as amended,
from time to time, by resolution of the Borough Council;
      (3)   Certification. The fee for official certification of copies, if an
official certification is requested by the requestor for the purpose of legally
verifying the public record, shall be in an amount as established, from time to
time, by resolution of Borough Council; and
      (4)   Conversion to paper. If a public record is only maintained
electronically or in other non-paper media, duplication fees shall be those
imposed by subsection (A)(2) above.
   (B)   Waiver of fees. The borough may waive the fees for duplication of a
public record including, but not limited to, when:
      (1)   The requestor duplicates the public record; and
      (2)   The borough deems it is in the public interest to do so.
   (C)   Prepayment. Prior to granting a request for access in accordance with
this Part, the borough may require a requestor to prepay an estimate of the
fees authorized under this section if the fees required to fulfill the request
are expected to exceed $100.
   (D)   Limitations. Except as otherwise provided by statute, no other fees
may be imposed unless the borough necessarily incurs costs for complying with
the request and such fees must be reasonable. No fee may be imposed for the
borough’s review of a record to determine whether the record is a public record
subject to access in accordance with 65 P.S. §§ 67.101 et seq.
   (E)   Setting fees. The fees shall be set from time to time by resolution of
the borough.
§ 1-608 BOROUGH CONTACT.
   The person at the borough to whom all record requests should be addressed
shall be:
 
Borough Manager
Borough of Dillsburg
151 S. Baltimore St.
Dillsburg, Pa. 17019
(717)432-9969
 
§ 1-609 REGULAR BUSINESS HOURS.
   The regular business hours of the borough shall be Monday through Friday 8:
00 a.m. to 4:30 p.m.
§ 1-610 PERSON DESIGNATED TO ACCEPT EXCEPTIONS FILED WHEN A RECORD IS DENIED.
   The individual at the borough who shall receive and respond to exceptions
filed when a record is denied and the requestor disagrees with the denial shall
be the Borough Manager.
§ 1-611 MISCELLANEOUS.
   (A)   The borough shall not ask for or require a purpose or motive for
requesting a particular record and shall not limit the number of public records
that may be requested.
   (B)   If the record is only kept in electronic form, the borough shall make
it available in paper on request.
   (C)   The borough will not create a record that does not exist or put a
document into a format that does not exist, except for subsection (B) above.
   (D)   This Part shall be posted prominently at the borough municipal
building.
CHAPTER 2: ANIMALS
      Part
         
1.   CUSTODY AND KEEPING OF ANIMALS AND FOWL

PART 1: CUSTODY AND KEEPING OF ANIMALS
AND FOWL
Section
   
2-101   Permit required
   
2-102   Limitation on number of dogs and cats
   
2-103   Running at large
   
2-104   Noise or disturbance to be controlled
   
2-105   Befouling sidewalks or property
   
2-106   Public events
   
2-107   Penalty
§ 2-101 PERMIT REQUIRED.
   (A)   It shall be unlawful for any person, firm, corporation or other entity
to engage in the keeping or housing of poultry, pigs, cattle, horses or other
undomesticated animals in the borough without first obtaining a permit from the
Secretary or Borough Manager for which there shall be no charge. All permits
are subject to the approval of Council, and shall be valid only until the
second regular Council meeting after originally issued. Council shall consider
the effect of keeping or housing such animals may have on the health, safety
and welfare of residents, the type of housing to be provided and the methods of
retention or fencing proposed or required. Council may require from the
applicant any additional information bearing on said health, safety and welfare
and may require specified standards of care from the applicant to overcome
reasonable objections.
   (B)   Council may extend the expiration date of the original permit for a
specified period of time prior to making a final determination. Upon approval,
the applicant shall be notified thereof, and his or her permit shall forthwith
become valid for an indefinite period; if disapproved, Council shall notify the
applicant of the reasons for disapproval, and the applicant shall remove such
animals within 30 days. Council may withdraw any permit issued for the keeping
or housing of poultry, pigs, cattle, horses or other undomesticated animals at
any time whenever such keeping or housing shall have a detrimental effect upon
the health, safety or welfare of the borough or its residents.
   (C)   If any permit be withdrawn, the person, firm or corporation affected
shall be notified in writing of the reasons therefor, and be ordered to remove
such poultry or other animals within a specified time not less than 30 days
from receipt of such notice.
(Ord. 144, passed 3-1-1979, Art. LX, § 6030)
§ 2-102 LIMITATION ON NUMBER OF DOGS AND CATS.
   It shall be unlawful for any person, firm or corporation having a right of
property in any dog or cat, or custody thereof, to keep more than four dogs and
cats, in aggregate number, more than six months of age, or older, on any
premises, regardless of the number of owners, except by permit.
   (A)   Application for permit. An application for a permit to keep more than
four dogs and cats in aggregate number over six months of age shall provide the
following information, and shall be accompanied by a verified veterinarian’s
health certificate for each dog or cat to be covered by the permit:
      (1)   Type and number of dogs and cats to be covered by the permit;
      (2)   The purpose for keeping such dogs or cats;
      (3)   The period for which the permit is requested;
      (4)   A description of the quarters in which the dogs or cats will be
maintained, including plans and specifications thereof, where appropriate, and
the facilities for sanitation and disposal of animal wastes;
      (5)   The circumstances under which the dogs or cats will be removed from
their quarters;
      (6)   Information about the applicant and any other person responsible
for the animals, with particular emphasis on the knowledge of such person about
the animals in question, and the experience of each person to serve in such
position of responsibility; and
      (7)   Such additional information as Council may require.
   (B)   Scope of information considered by borough. The foregoing information
shall be provided to Council at the next regular Council meeting held at least
ten days after the information is provided and Council shall determine whether
the permit shall be issued considering, among other things, the following:
      (1)   The odor likely to emanate from the premises to neighboring
premises;
      (2)   The noise likely to emanate from the premises to neighboring
premises;
      (3)   The attitude of the applicant’s neighbors in response to the
proposed permit; and
      (4)   The security with which the animals will be restrained.
   (C)   Council consideration. Council shall consider the issuance of a permit
for such housing at the meeting in which the information is provided, or
determine that additional information shall be required, and consider issuance
of the permit at the next regularly scheduled meeting of Council.
   (D)   Revocation. Any permit so issued may be revoked in accordance with
subsection (A) above.
   (E)   Permit fee. The fee for each permit issued shall be in an amount to be
established; from time to time, by resolution of Borough Council for each
calendar year, or part thereof; the application, with the appropriate
information, shall be accompanied by the appropriate fee which shall be the fee
due for the balance of the calendar year then remaining. Fees for successive
calendar years shall be paid on or before January 15 of each succeeding
calendar year.
(Ord. 144, passed 3-1-1979; Ord. 1988-3, passed 5-17-1988)
§ 2-103 RUNNING AT LARGE.
   (A)   Generally. It shall be unlawful for the owner, or custodian, of any
fowl or animal to permit such fowl or animal to run at large within the
borough. Running at large shall include an animal being upon any public
highway, street, alley, park or other public land, or upon the property of a
person other than the owner, or custodian, of the animal, without restraint or
control. The terms FOWL and ANIMAL shall include any domesticated fowl or
animal, regardless of whether the species is normally considered domesticated,
and shall specifically include dogs and cats, regardless of whether they are
licensed. If it be shown that any such fowl or animal was running at large, it
shall be presumed, for the purposes of this section, that such was permitted by
the owner, or custodian.
   (B)   Detention of animal running at large. Any police officer or designated
animal control service of the borough shall seize and detain any such fowl or
animal found running at large, whether upon the streets, alleys or highways of
the borough, or upon property other than that of the owner or custodian. Such
officer is hereby authorized and empowered to enter upon such premises, or into
any building to so seize and detain whenever he or she is in pursuit of such
fowl or animal.
(Ord. 144, passed 3-1-1979, Art. LX, § 6040; Ord. 1988-3, passed 5-17-1988)
§ 2-104 NOISE OR DISTURBANCE TO BE CONTROLLED.
   It shall be unlawful for any person who is the owner or custodian of any
fowl or animal to permit such fowl or animal to make any noise continuously
and/or incessantly for a period in excess of ten minutes, or to permit the
making of such noise intermittently for one-half hour or more which noise for
such a period or periods shall be considered a disturbance of other persons
within the borough, regardless of whether the fowl or animal is physically
situated upon private property; provided, however, that no person is
trespassing or threatening to trespass upon such private property upon which
the fowl or animal is situated, and there is no other legitimate cause which
justifiably provokes the fowl or animal.
(Ord. 2015-3, passed 10-13-2015)
§ 2-105 BEFOULING SIDEWALKS OR PROPERTY.
   It shall be unlawful for any person owning or having custody of any animal
or fowl to knowingly, or negligently, permit such animal or fowl to defecate or
urinate upon any public or private way, upon any structure situated in, or
adjacent to, a private way, or upon the ground of any public or private
property other than that of the owner of custodian of said animal or fowl. This
section shall not be effective if the owner or custodian shall within five
minutes of the animal’s or fowl’s defecation dispose of any feces in a toilet
or in a non-leaking container for deposit in a trash or litter receptacle.
(Ord. 2015-3, passed 10-13-2015)
§ 2-106 PUBLIC EVENTS.
   All animals are restricted and prohibited from public events. No person
shall bring, carry, accompany, covey or transport pets, animals or reptiles,
other than those actually participating in the event or which are certified
service and/or police dogs, within 100 feet of the route or site of such
function.
(Ord. 2015-3, passed 10-13-2015)
§ 2-107 PENALTY.
   Any person, firm, corporation or other entity who shall violate any
provision of this Part shall, upon conviction thereof, be sentenced to pay a
fine of not more than $1,000 plus costs and, in default of payment of said fine
and costs to a term of imprisonment not to exceed 30 days. Each day that a
violation of this Part continues or each section of this Part which shall be
found to have been violated shall constitute a separate offense.
(Ord. 2015-3, passed 10-13-2015)
PART 2: FREE ROAMING CATS
Section
   
2-201   Definitions
   
2-202   Nuisance
   
2-203   Penalty
   
2-204   Trapping and removing
§ 2-201 DEFINITIONS.
   For the purpose of this Part, the following definitions shall apply unless
the context clearly indicates or requires a different meaning.
   FREE ROAMING CAT.
      (1)   A cat born in the wild or that is the offspring of an owned or free
roaming cat that runs free without supervision; or
      (2)   A formerly owned cat that has been abandoned and runs free without
supervision.
   OWNER. The individual responsible for the animal, for both its wellbeing and
any destruction or damage which the animal may cause to any other person or
property.
(Ord. 2012-1, passed 6-12-2012)
§ 2-202 NUISANCE.
   Free roaming cats shall be considered a nuisance and it shall, therefore, be
unlawful for any person to cause or permit feeding of any free roaming cat
within the borough. Feeding of a cat not owned by the individual, or not having
knowledge of the specific owner by the individual, taking action to feed shall
be assumed to be the intention of the individual as to feed a free roaming cat
in violation of this Part. The exception to the Part is the placing of food
within a trap for the purpose of trapping a free roaming cat for removal or
other disposition in accordance with this Part.
(Ord. 2012-1, passed 6-12-2012)
§ 2-203 PENALTY.
   Anyone found in violation of any provisions of this Part shall, upon
conviction at a District Justice, be ordered to pay a penalty in an amount not
less than $500 for each separate act of feeding in violation of any provision
of this Part shall constitute a separate violation and be separate and distinct
penalties.
(Ord. 2012-1, passed 6-12-2012)
§ 2-204 TRAPPING AND REMOVING.
   Borough Council, in its discretion, may choose to trap and remove any free
roaming cat which the borough determines, in its sole discretion, to constitute
a nuisance or threat to the health, safety or welfare of a citizen or citizens
of the borough.
(Ord. 2012-1, passed 6-12-2012)
CHAPTER 3: RESERVED
CHAPTER 4: BUILDINGS

PART 1: NUMBERING OF BUILDINGS
Section
   
4-101   Numbering of buildings required
§ 4-101 NUMBERING OF BUILDINGS REQUIRED.
   Every owner of property in the borough whereon is erected any building,
whether a dwelling, commercial building or industrial building, or a building
used for any other purpose, is hereby required to affix or provide for the
affixing of the applicable number or numbers designated by the Borough Manager
thereon in compliance with the Uniform Construction Code.
   (A)   The following general plan for numbering of buildings is hereby
approved, as well as a certain plan of existing buildings prepared for Council
by the Dillsburg Jaycees dated January, 1960. Such plan is and shall be lodged
with the Borough Manager, and shall be revised from time to time as necessary.
Copies thereof shall be available to anyone upon payment of reproduction costs.
      (1)   The focal and starting point for numbers shall be the intersection
of Baltimore Street with Harrisburg Street.
      (2)   Proceeding either north or south from said focal point, numbers to
the right shall be even numbers starting with number 2 and continuing
consecutively; numbers to the left shall be odd numbers starting with number 1
and continuing consecutively.
      (3)   Proceeding either east or west from said focal point, numbers to
the right shall be even numbers starting with number 2 and continuing
consecutively; numbers to the left shall be odd numbers starting with number 1
and continuing consecutively.
   (B)   Owners shall affix or provide for the affixing of the proper number or
numbers in accordance with the general numbering plan in a conspicuous and
recognizable place and manner, and shall maintain or replace such numbers so
that they always be recognizable.
   (C)   Whenever any owner shall fail to affix or cause to be affixed proper
numbers, or shall fail to keep such numbers recognizable, the Borough Manager
shall notify him or her to affix or replace such number or numbers within ten
days from receipt of such notice.
   (D)   If any owner shall fail or refuse to affix numbers within ten days
after notice, Council may cause such numbers to be affixed, and shall collect
the sum in an amount to be established by resolution of Borough Council as the
charge therefor, as municipal assessments are collected.
   (E)   Failure or refusal to affix or replace numbers after notice shall be
considered a violation of this Part, and the responsible person, firm,
corporation or other entity shall upon conviction thereof shall be sentenced to
pay a fine of not more than $1,000 plus costs and, in default of payment of
said fine and costs, to a term of imprisonment not to exceed 30 days. Each day
the violation continues shall constitute a separate offense.
(Ord. 144, passed 3-1-1979, Art. LX, § 6000)
PART 2: PLACEMENT OF CONSTRUCTION AND BAG DUMPSTERS AND PORTABLE ON DEMAND
STORAGE UNITS
Section
   
4-201   Definitions
   
4-202   Dumpsters and portable on demand storage units permitted; regulated
   
4-203   Permit required
   
4-204   Abatement
   
4-205   Violations; penalties
   
4-206   Relationship of Part to other borough codes
§ 4-201 DEFINITIONS.
   For the purpose of this Part, the following definitions shall apply unless
the context clearly indicates or requires a different meaning.
   DUMPSTER. A container designed to receive and transport and dump waste which
exceeds 96 gallons in size. A DUMPSTER includes waste disposal bags that are
designed to hold in excess of 96 gallons of waste.
   PORTABLE ON-DEMAND STORAGE UNITS or PODS. Portable containers that are
placed on or in front of a property for the purpose of storing, loading or
unloading furniture, clothing or other personal or household belongings as part
of the process of renovation or moving, the relocation of belongings to an off-
site commercial storage location, or on-site storage in the aftermath of the
property being affected by a natural disaster.
(Ord. 2013-1, passed 11-12-2013)
§ 4-202 DUMPSTERS AND PORTABLE ON DEMAND STORAGE UNITS PERMITTED; REGULATED.
   Dumpsters and portable on-demand storage units are permitted and are hereby
regulated according to the provisions below.
   (A)   Dumpsters regulated.
      (1)   Location and size. Dumpsters shall be placed on the property being
serviced and not on the street in front of the property unless prior approval
is received by Borough Council. No dumpsters shall be located within ten feet
of an abutting building or an adjacent property and may not exceed 30 cubic
yards in volume without the express written consent of the borough after
providing evidence that all location and setback requirements can be met.
      (2)   Time limit.
         (a)   A construction or “bag” dumpster may remain on a property for 30
days, with up to two 30-day extensions pursuant to the permitting provision
below. Absent an emergency condition, in no event shall one of these dumpsters
remain on a property in excess of 90 days in one 12-month period.
         (b)   When the need for the dumpster is the result of an emergency
condition at the property to be served (e.g., water or fire damage; hurricane
damage) then in such instance the dumpster may remain for the length of time
necessary to remove the debris as determined by the borough. In such instances,
the use of the dumpster is not counted towards the limit of three times per 12-
month period.
      (3)   Sanitation. The following requirements shall be maintained while
the dumpster is on or at the site:
         (a)   The area around the dumpster shall be kept free of debris and
litter;
         (b)   Any dumpster into which animal or vegetable waste or material
has been dumped or deposited shall be removed or emptied within 24 hours;
         (c)   Any dumpster producing or causing noxious, foul or offensive
odors shall be immediately removed or cleaned to eliminate the odor; and
         (d)   A full dumpster shall be removed from the property within two
days.
      (4)   Usage. A dumpster shall only be used to contain and remove debris
and material generated at the location where the dumpster is placed.
      (5)   Identification. The name and telephone number of the owner of the
dumpster and/or the company that is responsible for the dumpster shall be
displayed in a weather proof manner on the dumpster.
   (B)   Portable on-demand storage units regulated.
      (1)   Location and size. Portable on-demand storage units are prohibited
from being placed on an unpaved area in the front yard of a property. Portable
storage units kept on-site must be kept in the driveway or paved, off-street
surface on the property at the furthest accessible point from the street. Where
possible, the unit shall be placed on a paved surface to the rear or side of
the principal structure. When placed on the driveway or paved area in the side
or rear yard, portable storage units shall be located at least ten feet from
any property line, space permitting. The portable on demand storage unit may be
no larger than eight feet by eight feet by 16 feet in size without the express
written consent of the borough after providing evidence that all location and
setback requirements can be met.
      (2)   Time limit. A portable on-demand storage unit may remain on a
property for 30 days, with up to two 30-day extensions pursuant to the
permitting provision below. Absent an emergency condition, in no event shall a
portable on-demand storage unit remain on a property in excess of 90 days in
one 12-month period.
      (3)   Use during natural disaster. The above restrictions
notwithstanding, when the principal structure on the property has been made
uninhabitable as a result of a natural disaster for which a local state of
emergency declaration has been issued, or a fire or other damaging event beyond
the control of the owner, one or more portable storage units may be used for
on-site storage. The authorization for such use shall be dependent on issuance
of a building permit for the reconstruction/repair of the principal structure
(s) on the property and shall expire upon issuance of a certificate of
occupancy for the principal structure(s) or 12 months from the date of the
event that damaged the structure, whichever occurs first. For good cause shown
and to recognize extenuating circumstances, the borough may extend the
authorization for as much as an additional 12-month period or until a
certificate of occupancy is issued, whichever occurs first.
      (4)   Advertising. Advertising is prohibited on a portable storage unit,
with the exception of the name and phone number of the unit’s supplier, which
is required.
      (5)   Hazardous materials. The use of portable storage units for storage
of hazardous materials is prohibited. The Code Enforcement Officer may inspect
the portable storage unit to ensure no such materials are being stored inside.
      (6)   Condition of portable storage unit. A portable storage unit with
holes, breaks, tears or large areas of rust, in the opinion of the Code
Enforcement Officer, may not be placed on or in front of any property.
(Ord. 2013-1, passed 11-12-2013)
§ 4-203 PERMIT REQUIRED.
   A 30-day permit shall be required for a construction and/or “bag” dumpster
and a portable on-demand storage unit. The permit shall be obtained from the
borough and the fee shall $10 and may be changed by the Council by resolution.
The permit shall be displayed in a weather-proof fashion on the dumpster or a
portable on-demand storage unit. Extensions are permitted pursuant to §
4-202(A)(2)(a) and (B)(2).
(Ord. 2013-1, passed 11-12-2013)
§ 4-204 ABATEMENT.
   Any dumpster or portable on-demand storage unit not in compliance with this
Part is hereby declared to be a public nuisance and may be abated by the
borough at the owner’s or responsible person’s expense. Abatement shall, at the
borough’s option, include the removal and/or the emptying of the dumpster and/
or portable on-demand storage unit as the case may be.
(Ord. 2013-1, passed 11-12-2013)
§ 4-205 VIOLATIONS; PENALTIES.
   (A)   Violation of any provision of this chapter shall be punishable by a
fine in an amount of not more than $1,000 plus $50 per day the violation
continues.
   (B)   In addition, a person found guilty of a violation of this chapter
shall be ordered to abate the problem and pay the cost incurred by the borough
if the borough abated the problem.
(Ord. 2013-1, passed 11-12-2013)
§ 4-206 RELATIONSHIP OF PART TO OTHER BOROUGH CODES.
   If the provisions of this Part are found to be inconsistent with any portion
of other codes of the borough, the provisions of this Part shall control.
(Ord. 2013-1, passed 11-12-2013)

PART 1: INTERNATIONAL PLUMBING CODE
Section
   
5-101   Adoption of Plumbing Code
   
5-102   Additions, insertions and changes
   
5-103   Definitions
   
5-104   Amendments made to the International Plumbing Code
§ 5-101 ADOPTION OF PLUMBING CODE.
   A certain document, three copies of which are on file in the office of the
Secretary of the Council of Dillsburg Borough, being marked and designated as
“The International Plumbing Code, 2021 Edition” and subsequent editions, be and
is hereby adopted as the Plumbing Code of the Borough of Dillsburg, York
County, in the State of Pennsylvania for the control of buildings and
structures; and each and all of the regulations, provisions, penalties,
conditions and terms of the International Plumbing Code, 2021 Edition, are
hereby referred to, adopted and made a part hereof, as if fully set out in this
Part, with the additions, insertions and changes, if any, prescribed in §
5-102 of this Part.
(Ord. 2001-5, passed 2-13-2001, § 1)
§ 5-102 ADDITIONS, INSERTIONS AND CHANGES.
   The following sections are hereby revised as follows:
   Cooperation of Other Officials. The code official (as later defined in the
Plumbing Code) may request and shall receive, so far as may be necessary in the
discharge is his or her duties, the assistance and cooperation of other
officials of the borough.
(Ord. 2001-5, passed 2-13-2001, § 2)
§ 5-103 DEFINITIONS.
   (A)   Wherever the word MUNICIPALITY or term NAME OF MUNICIPALITY is used in
the Plumbing Code, it shall be held to mean Dillsburg Borough.
   (B)   Wherever the term LEGAL REPRESENTATIVE or LEGAL OFFICIAL is used in
the Plumbing Code, it shall be held to mean the Solicitor of Dillsburg Borough.
   (C)   Wherever the term BUILDING or STRUCTURE is used in the Plumbing Code,
it shall be held to mean all buildings and structures within the Borough of
Dillsburg.
   (D)   Wherever the term APPOINTING AUTHORITY is used in the Plumbing Code as
adopted, it shall be held to mean the Council of Dillsburg Borough, York
County, Pennsylvania.
(Ord. 2001-5, passed 2-13-2001, § 3)
§ 5-104 AMENDMENTS MADE TO THE INTERNATIONAL PLUMBING CODE.
   The Plumbing Code hereby adopted is hereby amended and changed in the
following respects.
   (A)   Title. These regulations shall be known as the Plumbing Code of the
Borough of Dillsburg, also referred to herein as “this code”.
   (B)   Code Official - Duties and Power; General. The Code Official shall
enforce the provisions of this Code. The person appointed as Building Code
Officer by the Council of Dillsburg Borough shall function as and is herein
referred to as the “Code Official”.
   (C)   Violations; Violation Penalties. Any person, firm, corporation or
other entity who shall violate a provision of this Code or shall erect,
construct, alter, repair or maintain a building or structure in violation of an
approved plan or directive of the code official, or of a permit or certificate
issued under the provisions of this Code, shall be guilty of a violation of
this Code, and, upon conviction thereof before any magisterial district judge
of the borough or other court having jurisdiction over same, shall be sentenced
to pay a fine of not more than $1,000 and costs of prosecution for each
offense, and, in default of payment of such fine and costs, to imprisonment in
the county jail for not more than 30 days. The owner, tenant, lessee or
occupant of a building or structure or portion thereof, of the premises where
anything in violation of this Code shall be erected, constructed, altered,
repaired or maintained, and any architect, engineer, builder, contractor,
agent, person, partnership or corporation employed in connection therewith and
who may have participated or assisted in the commission of any such violation
shall each be guilty of a separate offense and, upon conviction thereof before
any magisterial district judge of the borough or other court having
jurisdiction over same, shall be sentenced to pay a fine of not more than
$1,000 and costs of prosecution for each offense, and, in default of payment of
such fine and costs, to imprisonment in the county jail for not more than 30
days. Each day that a violation continues shall be deemed a separate offense.
   (D)   Application for Appeal.
      (1)   Appeals may be taken by any person aggrieved by any decision of
interpretation by the Code Official or other authorized official to act
pursuant to this Code to the Board of Appeals. The members of the Council of
Dillsburg Borough shall act as the Board of Appeals. All appeals under this
section shall be filed within 15 days after notice of the decision of the Code
Official or other authorized official. The appeal shall be filed in duplicate
and shall be filed with the Code Official. One copy of the appeal shall be
given by the Code Official to any other official involved in the case. Parties
to the appeal shall be the person filing the appeal, the owner of any property
involved and the Code Official in his or her official capacity. The Code
Official shall not give less than ten days’ written notice of the hearing to
the parties.
      (2)   The Board of Appeals shall hold a public hearing within 30 days
after the appeal was filed. Unless the parties request a stenographically
recorded hearing, the testimony will be tape-recorded. If a stenographically
recorded hearing is requested, the party making the request shall pay the costs
thereof.
      (3)   The Board of Appeals shall not be bound by technical rules of
evidence, and all relevant evidence of reasonable probative value may be
permitted. Reasonable examination and cross examination shall be permitted.
      (4)   The Board of Appeals shall reach a written decision within 30 days
after the hearing, or if such a hearing is continued, within 30 days after the
continued hearing. Every decision shall be in writing and shall contain
findings and the reasons for the adjudication. Every decision shall be filed in
the office of the Code Official and shall be open to public inspection. A
certified copy of the decision shall be served upon all parties or their
counsel personally, or by mail, not later than five days following issuance of
the decision.
   (E)   Lead Pipes. Notwithstanding anything to the contrary set forth in said
Code the use of lead pipe and lead fittings shall not be permitted.
   (F)   Plastic Drain, Vent and Waste Piping. Where plastic drain, vent and
waste piping is permitted under said Code all plastic drain, vent and waste
piping shall be Schedule 40 minimum.
   (G)   Date of Effect. That this Part shall take effect on the first day of
the month after its date of enactment.
(Ord. 2001-5, passed 2-13-2001, § 4)
PART 2: INTERNATIONAL MECHANICAL CODE
Section
   
5-201   Adoption of Mechanical Code
   
5-202   Cooperation of other officials
   
5-203   Definitions
   
5-204   Amendments made to the International Mechanical Code
§ 5-201 ADOPTION OF MECHANICAL CODE.
   A certain document, three copies of which are on file in the office of the
Secretary of the Council of Dillsburg Borough at the Municipal Building, 151
South Baltimore Street, Dillsburg, York County, Pennsylvania, being marked and
designated as “The International Mechanical Code, 2021 Edition” and subsequent
editions, be and is hereby adopted as the Mechanical Code of the Borough of
Dillsburg, York County, Pennsylvania (hereinafter sometimes referred to as the
“Mechanical Code”); for the control of buildings and structures as herein
provided; and each and all of the regulations, provisions, penalties,
conditions and terms of said International Mechanical Code are hereby referred
to, adopted and made a part hereof, as if fully set out in this Part, with the
additions, insertions, deletions and changes, as applicable, prescribed in §
5-204 of this Part.
(Ord. 2001-6, passed 2-13-2001, § 1)
§ 5-202 COOPERATION OF OTHER OFFICIALS.
   The Code Official (as later defined in the Mechanical Code) may request and
shall receive, so far as may be necessary in the discharge is his or her
duties, the assistance and cooperation of other officials of the borough.
(Ord. 2001-6, passed 2-13-2001, § 2)
§ 5-203 DEFINITIONS.
   (A)   Wherever the word MUNICIPALITY or term NAME OF MUNICIPALITY is used in
the Mechanical Code, it shall be held to mean Dillsburg Borough.
   (B)   Wherever the term LEGAL REPRESENTATIVE or LEGAL OFFICIAL is used in
the Mechanical Code, it shall be held to mean the Solicitor of Dillsburg
Borough.
   (C)   Wherever the term BUILDING or STRUCTURE is used in the Mechanical
Code, it shall be held to mean all buildings and structures within the Borough
of Dillsburg.
   (D)   Wherever the term APPOINTING AUTHORITY is used in the Mechanical Code
as adopted, it shall be held to mean the Council of Dillsburg Borough, York
County, Pennsylvania.
(Ord. 2001-6, passed 2-13-2001, § 3)
§ 5-204 AMENDMENTS MADE TO THE INTERNATIONAL MECHANICAL CODE.
   The Mechanical Code hereby adopted is hereby amended and changed in the
following respects.
   (A)   Title. These regulations shall be known as the Mechanical Code of the
Borough of Dillsburg, also referred to herein as “this code”.
   (B)   Scope. These regulations shall apply, in general, to all matters
concerning the design, installation, maintenance, alteration and inspection of
mechanical systems, including heating systems, ventilating systems, cooling
systems, steam and hot water heating systems, water heaters, process piping,
boilers and pressure vessels, appliances utilizing gas, liquid or solid fuel,
chimneys and vents, mechanical refrigeration systems, fireplaces, barbecues,
incinerators, crematories and air pollution systems as herein defined.
   (C)   Other Regulations. When the provisions herein specified are more
restrictive in regard to specifications or requirements than other regulations
or ordinances, this Code shall control; but in any case, the strictest
requirements of either this Code or other regulation or ordinance shall apply
whenever a difference exists. Violation of such other regulation or ordinance
shall be considered a violation of this Code and, at the option of the borough,
the enforcement provisions (including penalties and fines) of this Code shall
be applied in lieu of enforcement provisions, if any, provided for in such
other regulation or ordinance. Notwithstanding the above, this Code shall not
control if this Code is identified by name and its application is expressly
restricted by such other ordinance or regulation, by provisions referenced in
such other ordinance or regulation or by provisions of this Code or ordinance.
   (D)   Code Official Duties. The creation and existence of the Department of
Mechanical Inspection of Dillsburg Borough is hereby reaffirmed and the
executive official in charge thereof shall be referred to herein as the “Code
Official”. Unless otherwise provided by resolution duly adopted of the Council
of Dillsburg Borough, the person appointed as Building Code Officer of
Dillsburg Borough by the Council shall function as the Code Official.
   (E)   Periodic Inspections. Fees for all periodic inspections shall be
included in permit fees applicable to the construction work.
   (F)   Penalties. Any person, firm, corporation or other entity who shall
violate a provision of this Code or shall fail to comply with any of the
requirements thereof or who shall erect, construct, alter or repair a building
or structure in violation of an approved plan or directive of the Code
Official, or of a permit or certificate issued under the provisions of this
Code, shall be guilty of a violation of this code, and, upon conviction thereof
before any magisterial district judge of the borough or other court having
jurisdiction over same, shall be sentenced to pay a fine of not more than
$1,000 and costs of prosecution for each offense, and, in default of payment of
such fine and costs, to imprisonment in the county jail for not more than 30
days. The owner, tenant, lessee or occupant of a building or structure of
portion thereof, or of the premises where anything in violation of this Code
shall be placed or shall exist, and any architect, engineer, builder,
contractor, agent, person, partnership or corporation employed in connection
therewith and who may have participated or assisted in the commission of any
such violation shall each be guilty of a separate offense and, upon conviction
thereof, before any magisterial district judge of the borough or other court
having jurisdiction of same, shall be sentenced to pay a fine of not more than
$1,000 and costs of prosecution, for each offense, and, in default of payment
thereof, to imprisonment in the county jail for not more than 30 days. Each day
that a violation continues shall be deemed a separate offense.
   (G)   Corrections. Should the owner, tenant, lessee or occupant fail to
remove or correct a condition in violation of this Code, then and in that
event, the Borough of Dillsburg may cause the same to be done and collect the
cost thereof, together with an administrative cost of 10% of such cost, in the
manner provided by law for the collection of municipal claims or by action of
assumpsit without the filing of a claim and/or may seek such other relief as
deemed appropriate.
   (H)   Unlawful Continuance. Any person, firm, corporation or other entity
who shall continue any work in or about the structure after having been served
with a stop-work order, except such work as that person, firm, corporation or
other entity is directed to perform to remove a violation or unsafe condition,
shall be subject to a fine of not more than $1,000, plus costs, in addition to
any other fines or penalties imposed by this Code or other ordinance. Each day
that a violation continues shall be deemed a separate offense.
   (I)   Application for Appeal. Appeals may be taken by any person aggrieved
by any decision of interpretation by the Code Official or other authorized
official to act pursuant to this Code to the Board of Appeals. The members of
the Council of Dillsburg Borough shall act as the Board of Appeals. All appeals
under this section shall be filed within 15 days after notice of the decision
of the Code Official or other authorized official. The appeal shall be filed in
duplicate and shall be filed with the Code Official. One copy of the appeal
shall be given by the Code Official to any other Official involved in the case.
Parties to the appeal shall be the person filing the appeal, the owner of any
property involved and the Code Official in his or her official capacity. The
Code Official shall not give less than ten days’ written notice of the hearing
to the parties.
      (1)   The Board of Appeals shall hold a public hearing within 30 days
after the appeal was filed. Unless the parties request a stenographically
recorded hearing, the testimony will be tape-recorded. If a stenographically
recorded hearing is requested, the party making the request shall pay the costs
thereof.
      (2)   The Board of Appeals shall not be bound by technical rules of
evidence, and all relevant evidence of reasonable probative value may be
permitted. Reasonable examination and cross examination shall be permitted.
      (3)   The Board of Appeals shall reach a written decision within 30 days
after the hearing, or if such a hearing is continued, within 30 days after the
continued hearing. Every decision shall be in writing and shall contain
findings and the reasons for the adjudication. Every decision shall be filed in
the office of the Code Official and shall be open to public inspection. A
certified copy of the decision shall be served upon all parties or their
counsel personally, or by mail, not later than five days following issuance of
the decision.
(Ord. 2001-6, passed 2-13-2001, § 4)
PART 3: INTERNATIONAL BUILDING CODE
Section
   
5-301   Adoption of Building Code
   
5-302   Cooperation of other officials
   
5-303   Definitions
   
5-304   Amendments made to the International Building Code
§ 5-301 ADOPTION OF BUILDING CODE.
   Certain documents, three copies of which are on file in the office of the
Secretary of the Borough of Dillsburg, at the Municipal Building, 151 South
Baltimore Street, Dillsburg, Pennsylvania, being marked and designated as “The
International Building Code, 2021 Edition” and subsequent editions, and “The
International Residential Code, 2021 Edition” and subsequent editions as
published, be and are hereby adopted as the Building Code of the Borough of
Dillsburg, York County, Pennsylvania (hereinafter sometimes referred to as the
“Building Code”), for the control of buildings and structures as herein
provided; and each and all of the regulations, provisions, penalties,
conditions and terms of said International Codes are hereby referred to,
adopted and made a part thereof, as if fully set out in this Part, with the
additions, insertions, deletions and changes, as applicable, prescribed in §
5-304 of this Part. Section 113 regulates violations; §§ 114 and 115 regulates
abatement and continuance of violations; and § 112 regulates appeals.
(Ord. 2001-6, passed 2-13-2001, § 1; Ord. 2002-1, passed 2-12-2002, § 1)
§ 5-302 COOPERATION OF OTHER OFFICIALS.
   The Code Official (as later defined in the Building Code) may request and
shall receive, so far as may be necessary in the discharge of his or her
duties, the assistance and cooperation of other officials of the borough.
(Ord. 2001-6, passed 2-13-2001, § 2)
§ 5-303 DEFINITIONS.
   (A)   Wherever the word MUNICIPALITY or term NAME OF MUNICIPALITY is used in
the Building Code, it shall be held to mean the Borough of Dillsburg.
   (B)   Wherever the term LEGAL REPRESENTATIVE or LEGAL OFFICIAL is used in
the Building Code, it shall be held to mean the Solicitor of the Borough of
Dillsburg.
   (C)   Wherever the term BUILDING or STRUCTURE is used in the Building Code,
it shall be held to mean all buildings and structures within the Borough of
Dillsburg.
   (D)   Whenever the term DATE OF ADOPTION OF THIS CODE is used in the
Building Code, it shall be held to mean the date of enactment of this Part.
   (E)   Wherever the term APPOINTING AUTHORITY is used in the Building Code as
adopted, it shall be held to mean the Borough Council of the Borough of
Dillsburg, York County, Pennsylvania.
(Ord. 2001-6, passed 2-13-2001, § 3)
§ 5-304 AMENDMENTS MADE TO THE INTERNATIONAL BUILDING CODE.
   The Building Code hereby adopted is hereby amended and changed in the
following respects.
   (A)   Section 101.1 Title. These regulations shall be known as the Building
Code of the Borough of Dillsburg, also referred to herein as “this Code”.
   (B)   Section 104.1 Building Code Officer/Code Official. It shall be the
duty and responsibility of the Building Code Officer to enforce the provisions
of this Code. The Building Code Officer shall function as the Code Official and
shall be referred to herein as the “Code Official”.
   (C)   Section 113 Penalty for Violations. Any person, firm, corporation or
other entity who shall violate a provision of this Code or shall fail to comply
with any of the requirements thereof or who shall erect, construct, alter,
repair or maintain a building or structure in violation of an approved plan or
directive of the Code Official, or of a permit or certificate issued under the
provisions of this Code, shall be guilty of a violation of this Code, and, upon
conviction thereof before any magisterial district judge of the borough or
other court having jurisdiction over same, shall be sentenced to pay a fine of
not more than $1,000 and costs of prosecution for each offense, and, in default
of payment of such fine and costs, to imprisonment in the county jail for not
more than 30 days. The owner, tenant, lessee or occupant of a building or
structure or portion thereof, or of the premises where anything in violation of
this Code shall be erected, constructed, altered, repaired or maintained, and
any architect, engineer, builder, contractor, agent, person, partnership or
corporation employed in connection therewith and who may have assisted in the
commission of any such violation shall each be guilty of a separate offense
and, upon conviction thereof before any magisterial district judge of the
borough or other court having jurisdiction over same, shall be sentenced to pay
a fine of not more than $1,000 and costs of prosecution for each offense, and,
in default of payment thereof, to imprisonment in the county jail for not more
than 30 days. Each day that a violation continues shall be deemed a separate
offense.
   (D)   Sections 114 and 115 Abatement/Continuance of Violation. Should the
owner, agent or occupier fail to remove or repair a dangerous building or
structure, then and in that event, the borough may cause the same to be done
and collect the cost thereof, together with administrative fee of an additional
10% of such cost, in the manner provided by law for the collection of municipal
claims or by action of assumpsit without the filing of a claim and/or may seek
such other relief as deemed appropriate.
   (E)   Section 112 Application for Appeal. Appeals may be taken by any person
aggrieved by any decision or interpretation by the Code Official or other
authorized official to act pursuant to this Code to the Board of Appeals. The
members of the Council of the Borough of Dillsburg shall act as the Board of
Appeals. Sections 121.2 through 121.6 (including all subsections thereof) of
this Code are deleted and replaced by a new § 121.2, which shall read as
follows: “All appeals under this section shall be filed within 15 days after
notice of the decision of the Code Official or other authorized official. The
written appeal, in duplicate, shall be filed with the Code Official. One copy
of the appeal shall be given by the Code Official to any other official
involved in the case. Parties to the appeal shall be the person filing the
appeal, the owner of any property involved and the Code Official in his or her
official capacity. The Code Official shall give not less than ten days’ written
notice of the hearing to the parties”.
      (1)   The Board of Appeals shall hold a public hearing within 30 days
after the appeal was filed. Unless the parties request a stenographically
recorded hearing, the testimony will be tape-recorded. If a stenographically
recorded hearing is requested, the party making the request shall pay the costs
thereof.
      (2)   The Board of Appeals shall not be bound by technical rules of
evidence, and all relevant evidence of reasonable probative value may be
permitted. Reasonable examination and cross examination shall be permitted.
      (3)   The Board of Appeals shall, reach a written decision within 30 days
after a hearing, or if such a hearing is continued, within 30 days after the
continued hearing. Every decision shall be in writing and shall contain
findings and the reasons for the adjudication. Every decision shall be filed in
the office of the Code Official and shall be open to public inspection. A
certified copy of the decision shall be served upon all parties or their
counsel personally, or by mail, not later than five days following issuance of
the decision.
(Ord. 2001-6, passed 2-13-2001, § 4)
