otherwise as permitted by law and to be used, developed or built upon as a
unit.
         (a)   CORNER LOT. A lot at the junction of and abutting on two or more
intersecting streets or private roads or at the point of abrupt change of a
single street or private road, where the interior angle is less than 135
degrees and the centerline radius of the street or private road line is less
than 100 feet. A front setback shall be provided from each street frontage and
a side setback shall be provided from all other property lines. However, if one
of the street frontages is a service drive, then the lot shall be regulated as
an interior lot and shall have front, side and rear setbacks. See diagrams at
the end of the chapter.
         (b)   DOUBLE FRONTAGE LOT. A lot extending between and having frontage
on two streets. Vehicular access can be from either or both streets. Also
referred to as a THROUGH LOT. DOUBLE FRONTAGE LOTS, or THROUGH LOTS, are not
permitted. See diagrams at the end of the chapter.
         (c)   INTERIOR LOT. A lot having frontage on one street and adjoined
on the sides and rear by other lots. INTERIOR LOTS shall have front, side and
rear setbacks. See diagrams at the end of the chapter.
         (d)   REVERSE FRONTAGE LOT. A lot extending between and having
frontage on a minor street and either an arterial or collector street with
vehicular access solely from the minor street. The front setback requirement
for the district in which the lot is located shall apply to both street
frontages. See diagrams at the end of the chapter.
         (e)   TRIPLE FRONTAGE LOT. A lot fronting on three streets. A front
setback shall be provided from each street frontage and a side setback shall be
provided from all remaining property lines. See diagrams at the end of the
chapter.
      (2)   However, if one of the street frontages is a service drive, then
the LOT shall be regulated as a corner lot or a double frontage lot, whichever
is applicable, and shall have only two front setbacks. If two of the street
frontages are service drives, then the LOT shall be regulated as an interior
lot and shall have front, side and rear setbacks. See diagrams at the end of
the chapter.
   LOT COVERAGE (MAXIMUM). A percentage which when multiplied by the lot area
will determine the permitted area that can be covered with buildings and
structures.
   LOT WIDTH. The width of the lot measured at the required front building
line.
   MEDICAL CLINIC. Any building or group of buildings occupied by medical
practitioners and related services for the purpose of providing health services
to persons on an outpatient basis.
   MEDICAL MARIJUANA. Marijuana for certified medical use in the Commonwealth
of Pennsylvania as set forth in Act No. 16 of 2016, also known as the Medical
Marijuana Act, being 35 P.S. §§ 10231 et seq.
   MEDICAL MARIJUANA DISPENSARY. The use of a premises by a natural person,
corporation, partnership, association, trust or other entity, or any
combination thereof, holding a legal permit issued by the Pennsylvania
Department of Health, to dispense medical marijuana in accordance with Act No.
16 of 2016, also known as the Medical Marijuana Act.
   MEDICAL MARIJUANA GROWER/PROCESSOR. The use of the premises by a person,
including a natural person, corporation, partnership, association, trust or
other entity, or any combination thereof, holding a legal permit from the
Pennsylvania Department of Health, to grow and/or process medical marijuana,
with all growing and processing activity to be conducted indoors.
   MINI-STORAGE FACILITY. A facility providing for the enclosed storage of
commercial business stock or equipment, household items, seasonal equipment
and/or classic or antique automobiles where said items are retained for direct
use by their owner who shall have direct access thereto without intermediate
handling by the proprietor of the facility.
   MOBILE HOME. A transportable, single-family dwelling intended for permanent
occupancy, contained in one unit, or in two or more units designed to be joined
into one integral unit capable of again being separated for repeated towing,
which arrives at a site complete and ready for occupancy except for minor and
incidental unpacking and assembly operations, and construction so that it may
be used without a permanent foundation.
   MOBILE HOME LOT. A parcel of land in a mobile home park, improved with the
necessary utility connections and other appurtenances necessary for the
erection thereon of a single mobile home.
   MOBILE HOME PARK. A parcel or contiguous parcels of land which has been so
designated and improved that it contains two or more mobile home lots for the
placement thereon of mobile homes.
   NEIGHBORHOOD PARK OR PLAYGROUND. An area developed, managed and conserved to
provide outdoor recreational opportunities for the neighborhood in which it is
located. The types of recreational activities to be permitted include passive
recreational facilities, such as picnic areas, natural trails, bicycle paths
and gardens; and active recreational facilities, such as children’s play
equipment, turf area for field games, and hard surface areas for court games.
Use of the facilities in a neighborhood park or playground shall not require
the payment of any fees.
   NO-IMPACT HOME-BASED BUSINESS.
      (1)   A business or commercial activity administered or conducted as an
accessory use which is clearly secondary to the use as a residential dwelling
and which involves no customer, client or patient traffic, whether vehicular or
pedestrian, pickup, delivery or removal functions to or from the premises, in
excess of those normally associated with residential use.
      (2)   The business or commercial activity must satisfy the following
requirements:
         (a)   The business activity shall be compatible with the residential
use of the property and surrounding residential uses;
         (b)   The business shall employ no employees other than family members
residing in the dwelling;
         (c)   There shall be no display or sale of retail goods and no
stockpiling or inventory of a substantial nature;
         (d)   There shall be no outside appearance of a business use,
including, but not limited to, parking, signs or lights;
         (e)   The business activity may not use any equipment or process which
creates noise, vibration, glare, fumes, odors or electrical or electronic
interference, including interference with radio or television reception, which
is detectable in the neighborhood;
         (f)   The business activity may not generate any solid waste or sewage
discharge, in volume or type, which is not normally associated with residential
use in the neighborhood;
         (g)   The business activity shall be conducted only within the
dwelling and may not occupy more than 25% of the habitable floor area; and
         (h)   The business may not involve any illegal activity.
   NONCONFORMITY. A use, structure, lot or dimension in conflict with the
regulations of this chapter, existing on the effective date of this chapter, or
existing at any subsequent amendment of this chapter, or created by variance.
Specifically, the following types of nonconformities are distinguished.
      (1)   NONCONFORMING LOT. A lot the area or dimension of which was lawful
prior to the adoption or amendment of this chapter, but which fails to conform
to the requirements of the zoning district in which it is located by reasons of
such adoption or amendment.
      (2)   NONCONFORMING STRUCTURE. A structure or part of a structure
manifestly not designed to comply with the applicable use or extent of use
provisions in this chapter or any amendment heretofore or hereafter enacted,
where such structure lawfully existed prior to the enactment of this chapter or
amendment or prior to the application of this chapter or amendment to its
location by reason of annexation. Such nonconforming structures include, but
are not limited to, nonconforming signs.
      (3)   NONCONFORMING USE. A use, whether of land or of a structure, which
does not comply with the applicable use or extent of use provisions in this
chapter or any amendment heretofore or hereafter enacted, where such use was
lawfully in existence prior to the enactment of this chapter or amendment, or
prior to the application of this chapter or amendment to its location by reason
of annexation.
   NONPROFIT. An educational, religious or charitable use which qualifies as
“non-profit” under § 501-C of the Internal Revenue Service Code.
   OUTDOOR COMMERCIAL RECREATION ESTABLISHMENT. A use of open land for leisure
time activities, such as a swimming pool, tennis court, golf driving range,
miniature, golf, golf course or drive-in theater that involves the payment of a
fee.
   OWNER. The owner of record of a parcel of land.
   PARKING GARAGE. A building where passenger vehicles may be stored for short-
term, daily or overnight off-street parking.
   PARKING LOT. An open lot where passenger vehicles may be stored for short-
term, daily or overnight off-street parking.
   PARKING SPACE. An off-street space available for the parking of one motor
vehicle and having direct usable access to a street or service drive.
   PERSONAL SERVICE BUSINESS. Includes barber and beauty shops; self-service
laundry and dry cleaning establishments; laundromats; radio and television
repair; repair shops for home appliances, tools, bicycles, guns, locks, shoes
and watches; tailor and dressmaking shops or any other establishment of similar
nature providing personalized service to customers.
   PLANNING CODE. The Pennsylvania Municipalities Planning Code, Act of July
31,1968, P.L. 805, Act 247, 53 P.S. § 10101, ff., as reenacted and amended.
   PREMISES. Any lot, parcel or tracts of land and any improvements constructed
or placed thereon.
   PRINCIPAL USE. See USE.
   PRIVATE. Not publicly owned, operated or controlled.
   PROFESSIONAL/BUSINESS OFFICE COMPLEX. A building or group of buildings
designed for use as professional and/or business offices.
   PROFESSIONAL OFFICE. An area, room, or rooms used for carrying on the
following professional occupations recognized by the Commonwealth of
Pennsylvania and requiring a certification of practice:
      (1)   Accountants;
      (2)   Architects;
      (3)   Attorneys;
      (4)   Chiropractors;
      (5)   Dentists;
      (6)   Engineers;
      (7)   Insurance agents;
      (8)   Insurance brokers;
      (9)   Nurses;
      (10)   Optometrists;
      (11)   Osteopaths;
      (12)   Physicians;
      (13)   Podiatrists;
      (14)   Psychiatrists;
      (15)   Psychologists;
      (16)   Real estate brokers;
      (17)   Surgeons; and
      (18)   Surveyors.
   PROPERTY LINES. The lines bounding a lot as described in the recorded title.
Also referred to as LOT LINES.
   PUBLIC. Owned, operated or controlled by a government agency (federal, state
or local; including a corporation created by law for the performance of certain
specialized governmental functions and the Board of Public Education).
   QUARRY. Land used for the purpose of extracting stone, sand, clay, gravel,
top soil or other mineral for sale, and exclusive of the process of grading a
lot preparatory to the construction of a building for which application for a
building permit has been made.
   RECREATIONAL VEHICLE. Any portable or mobile vehicle used or designed to be
used for travel recreation, and/or temporary living purposes; regardless of any
other intended use and whether or not its wheels, rollers or skids are in
place. A RECREATIONAL VEHICLE shall include trailer, camper, boat, boat
trailer, snowmobile, three or four wheel all-terrain vehicle, trail/dirt bike,
airplane or other similar vehicle which may provide partial and usually
temporary living and sleeping quarters and which may or may not include kitchen
and/or bathroom conveniences.
   RETAIL STORE OR SHOP. Any shop or store whose primary activities involve the
sale or lease of amusements and games, antiques, art, books, beverages, carpets
and rugs, ceramics and glass, confections, drugs, dry goods, flowers, food,
furniture, gifts, garden supplies, hobbies, hardware, household appliances,
household pets and supplies, leather goods, musical supplies and equipment,
notions, paint, periodicals, photographs and photographic equipment, radio,
television and sound equipment, sporting and camping goods, stationery,
tobacco, toys and wearing apparel. The wholesale distribution or manufacture of
the foregoing products are not included herein and are permitted only as
provided in other appropriate sections of this chapter. Among the uses not to
be interpreted as a retail store or business are uses specifically provided for
elsewhere in this chapter, including, but not limited to, a service station,
vehicular sales and/or rental facility, eating establishment, tavern, adult
regulated facility, hotel or motel, personal service business, and heavy
storage sales facility.
   RIGHT-OF-WAY. A right of passage across land occupied or intended to be
occupied by a street, crosswalk, railroad, electric transmission line, oil or
gas pipeline, water main, sanitary or storm sewer main, or for another special
use. If the RIGHT-OF-WAY involves maintenance by a public agency, it shall be
dedicated to public use by the maker of the plat on which such right-of-way is
established.
   ROOMING HOUSE. A residential building, other than a hotel, containing not
more than one dwelling unit where lodging is provided with or without meals for
compensation, for at least three, but not more than 15, persons in addition to
the family unit. No medical or personal care is provided to roomers by the
operators of the facility.
   SCHOOL.
      (1)   SCHOOL. Any place offering instruction in any branch of knowledge
under the supervision of the Commonwealth of Pennsylvania or a lawfully
constituted ecclesiastical governing body, person, partnership or corporation
meeting the requirements of the Commonwealth of Pennsylvania.
      (2)   COMMERCIAL SCHOOL. A school conducted for profit for such special
instruction as business, art, music, trades, handicraft or dancing.
   SCREEN PLANTING. A vegetation material of sufficient height and density to
conceal from the view of passing motorists and adjacent property owners the
structures and uses on the premises on which the screen planting is located.
   SEMI-PUBLIC. Owned, operated or controlled by a private or non-profit
organization of a public service nature and duly recognized as such by the
Commonwealth of Pennsylvania.
   SERVICE DRIVE. A minor right-of-way which is used to provide secondary
vehicular access to the rear or side of two or more properties whose frontage
is on some other street. Also referred to as a LANE or ALLEY.
   SETBACK. The required distance that buildings and structures must be set
back from street or property lines. For purposes of SETBACK, a service drive
right-of-way line shall not be considered a street line.
      (1)   FRONT SETBACK. The required distance between a street line, other
than a street line of a service drive, (regardless whether the same is also a
front, side or rear property line) and the front setback line projected the
full width of the lot. See diagrams at the end of this chapter. See SERVICE
DRIVE.
      (2)   REAR SETBACK. The required distance between the rear property line,
unless such line is also a street line other than a street line of a service
drive, and the rear setback line projected the full width of the lot. See
diagrams at the end of this chapter. See SERVICE DRIVE.
      (3)   SIDE SETBACK. The required distance between the side property line,
unless such line is also a street line other than a street line of a service
drive, and the side setback line projected from the front setback line to the
opposite setback line. However, in the case of corner lots, the second side
setback shall be the required distance between the rear lot line and the side
setback line projected from the side lot line to the opposite front setback
line. See diagrams at the end of this chapter. See SERVICE DRIVE.
   SETBACK LINE. A line within a property and parallel to a property or street
line which delineates the required minimum distance that must be provided
between a structure or building and an adjacent street line and/or property
line.
   SEXUAL CONDUCT. Ultimate sexual acts, normal or perverted, actual or
simulated, involving a person or persons, or a person or persons and an animal,
including acts of masturbation, sexual intercourse, fellatio, cunnilingus,
analingus or physical contact, including fondling or other erotic touching,
with a person’s nude or partially denuded genitals, pubic area, perineum, anal
region, or, if such person be female, a breast.
   SEXUAL DEVICE. An artificial human penis, vagina or anus, or other device
primarily designed to stimulate or manipulate the human genitals, pubic area,
perineum or anal area, including dildoes, penisators, vibrators, vibrillators,
penis rings and erection enlargement or prolonging creams, jellies or other
such chemicals or preparations.
   SEXUALLY EXPLICIT NUDITY. A sexually oriented and explicit showing or
exhibition, by any means or manner, which presents or exposes to the viewer the
following anatomical areas the human genitals, pubic area, perineum, buttocks
or anal region, with less than a fully opaque covering; the covered human male
genitals in a discernible turgid state; the postpubertal, full or partially
developed human female breast with less than opaque covering of a portion
thereof below the top of the areola or nipple.
   SERVICE STATION. Any area of land, including structures thereon, that is
used for the sale of gasoline or any other motor vehicle fuel and oil and other
lubricating substances, including any sales of motor vehicle accessories at
retail only, but not including major repairing, body and fender work, painting,
vehicular sales or rental or automatic car washes.
   SHOPPING CENTER OR MALL. A group of stores planned and designed to function
as a unit for the lot on which it is located with off-street parking provided
as an integral part of the unit.
   SIGN. Any surface, fabric, device or structure (including billboards or
poster panel) bearing lettered, pictorial or sculptured matter designed for
visual communication and used for the purpose of bringing the subject thereof
to the attention of the public, but not including any flag, badge or insignia
of any government agency or any civic, charitable, religious, fraternal or
similar organization, or any official traffic control sign or device.
      (1)   ADVERTISING SIGNAL. A sign whose major purpose is for directing
attention to a business commodity, service or entertainment conducted, sold or
offered elsewhere than upon the same lot, such as billboards.
      (2)   ATTACHED SIGN. A sign attached, painted or otherwise mounted
parallel to the surface of that portion of the building or structure to which
it is affixed.
      (3)   BUSINESS SIGN. A sign directing attention to a business or
profession conducted on the same lot or, as incidental to a business, to
products sold upon the same lot.
      (4)   DIRECTIONAL SIGN. A sign which directs people to a community; an
event of public interest; public uses and buildings; uses and buildings of
service and charitable organizations; and uses and buildings of commercial
nature provided that no advertising matter other than identifying name or
symbol shall be contained on signs of this type.
      (5)   FREESTANDING SIGN. A sign supported by uprights or braces placed
upon or in the ground and not attached to a building.
      (6)   PERMANENT SIGN. A sign permanently attached or applied to a
building or structure or permanently anchored into the ground and which cannot
easily be moved. PERMANENT SIGNS may have either permanent or replaceable
lettering.
      (7)   PORTABLE SIGN. A temporary sign, of any material, with or without
changeable type lettering, illuminated or non-illuminated, mounted or
transported on a vehicle, trailer or similar structure, with or without wheels,
and not permanently attached to the ground, often referred to as a MOBILE SIGN.
      (8)   PROJECTING SIGN. A sign which is attached to a building or other
structure and extends beyond the line of a building or structure or beyond the
surface of that portion of the building or structure to which it is attached.
      (9)   SIDEWALK SIGN. Any “A” frame, inverted “V” shaped or similar
structure resting on the ground with no permanent attachment and used for
display as a temporary commercial business sign.
      (10)   TEMPORARY SIGN. A sign which is anchored to the ground or attached
to a building or structure with weights, cables, pins, braces or stakes and
which can easily be moved. TEMPORARY SIGNS are displayed for a limited period
of time.
   SMALL PROCESSING ESTABLISHMENT. A commercial enterprise in which the
principal use involves light processing and/or repair, in conjunction with
retail sales or personal service, such as an opticians’ office and optical
laboratory. Such establishments shall not exceed 2,000 square feet of ground
floor area.
   SPECIAL EXCEPTION. The granting of the right to use land and/or structures
in a district for a purpose other than that generally permitted outright in
that district. A SPECIAL EXCEPTION is granted by the Zoning Hearing Board under
the terms, procedures and conditions prescribed herein.
   SPECIALTY CENTER. A retail and/or office center whose shops/offices cater to
a specific market and are linked together by an architectural, historical or
geographic theme or by a commonality of goods and services; also known as a
theme or fashion center.
   STORY.
      (1)   HALF STORY. A story under a gable, hip or gambrel roof, the wall
plates of which on at least two opposite exterior walls are not more than two
feet above the floor.
      (2)   STORY. That portion of a building, excluding cellars, included
between the surface of any floor and the surface of the floor next above it, or
if there be no floor above it, then the space between any floor and the ceiling
next above it.
   STREET. A public or private way, excluding driveways and access drives,
which affords the principal means of access to abutting properties, intended to
be used by vehicular traffic or pedestrians. Includes street, avenue,
boulevard, road, highway, freeway, parkway, lane, alley, service drive, viaduct
and any other dedicated and accepted public right-of-way or private right-of-
way.
   STREET LINE. A line defining the edge of a street right-of-way and
separating the street from abutting property or lots. Commonly known as the
STREET RIGHT-OF-WAY LINE.
   STRUCTURE.
      (1)   ACCESSORY STRUCTURES. A subordinate structure or a portion of the
principal building or structure on a lot, the use of which is customarily
incidental to that of the principal building or structure.
      (2)   STRUCTURE. Any human-made object having an ascertainable stationary
location on or in land or water, whether or not affixed to the land, but
excluding driveways, walkways and parking areas. All STRUCTURES must meet
setback requirements. See BUILDING.
   SWIMMING POOL. Any pool or open tank containing, or normally capable of
containing, water to a depth at any point greater than one and one-half feet.
Farm ponds and/or lakes are not included, provided that swimming was not the
primary purpose for their construction.
   TAVERN. An establishment which serves primarily alcoholic beverages for
mostly on-premises consumption and which is licensed by the Pennsylvania Liquor
Control Board. TAVERNS may also serve food.
   USE. The specific purpose for which land or a structure is designed,
arranged, intended, occupied, or maintained. The term PERMITTED USE or its
equivalent shall not be deemed to include any nonconforming use.
      (1)   ACCESSORY USE. A use customarily incidental and subordinate to the
principal use or building and located on the same lot with this principal use
or building.
      (2)   PRINCIPAL USE. The main or primary use of property, buildings, or
structures. Only one use permitted by right, by special exception, or as a
conditional use shall be permitted as a principal use on an individual lot
except as provided in §
27-432(C) of this chapter. For example only one single-family dwelling, one
commercial establishment, or one industrial establishment shall be permitted on
an individual lot. Complexes listed as permitted uses, such as a business park,
industrial park, professional/business office complex, or shopping center or
mall, shall be limited to one such complex per lot.
   USE CERTIFICATE. A certificate, issued by the Zoning Officer, which permits
the use of a building in accordance with the approved plans and specifications
and certifies compliance with the provisions of law for the use and occupancy
of the land and structure in its several parts, together with any special
stipulations or conditions of the building permit.
   VARIANCE. The permission, granted by the Zoning Hearing Board under the
terms, procedures and conditions prescribed herein, for a particular
modification to some regulation or provision of the zoning regulations of this
chapter which, if strictly adhered to, would result in an unnecessary hardship,
and where the permission granted would not be contrary to the public interest
and would maintain the spirit and intent of this chapter.
   VEHICLE SALES OR RENTAL FACILITY. An open lot for the outdoor display of new
or used automobiles, recreational vehicles and similar vehicles when accessory
to a vehicle sales, rental or display building.
   VEHICLE SERVICE AND REPAIR FACILITY. A building on a lot designed and/or
used primarily for mechanical and/or body repairs, storage, servicing, or
supplying of gasoline or oil to automobiles, recreational vehicles and similar
vehicles.
   VEHICLE WASHING FACILITY. A building on a lot, designed and used primarily
for the washing and polishing of automobiles and which may provide accessory
services related to washing and polishing.
   WAREHOUSE. A structure to be used for storage only of equipment and
merchandise.
   WHOLESALE ESTABLISHMENT. A business devoted to the sale of commodities in
quantity chiefly to retailers, other merchants, or industrial, institutional
and commercial users mainly for resale or business use. Such commodities shall
be limited to durable goods, sundries, dry goods and non- perishable items.
   YARD. A prescribed open area on a lot, unobstructed from the ground upward,
except as otherwise permitted by this chapter.
      (1)   FRONT YARD. A yard extending the full width of the lot and situated
between the street line and the front wall of the principal building projected
to the side property lines of the lot. See diagrams at the end of this chapter.
      (2)   REAR YARD. A yard extending the full width of the lot and situated
between the rear property line of the lot and the rear wall of the principal
building projected to the side property lines of the lot. See diagrams at the
end of this chapter.
      (3)   SIDE YARD. A yard situated between the side wall of the principal
building and the side property line of the lot and extending from the front
yard to the rear yard. Any yard not a rear yard or a front yard shall be deemed
a SIDE YARD. See diagrams at the end of this chapter.
(Ord. 171, passed 1-18-1972, Art. II, § 202; Ord. 213, passed 3-29-1979; Ord.
1987-2, passed 10-20-1987; Ord. 1993-2, passed 2-16-1993; Ord. 1997-04, passed
3-18-1997; Ord. 2000-1, passed 5-9-2000, § 2; Ord. 2022-1, passed 12-13-2022)
PART 3: DESIGNATION OF DISTRICTS
Section
   
27-301   Districts
   
27-302   Zoning map
   
27-303   District boundaries
   
27-304   Interpretation of boundaries
   
27-305   Use adjustment on district boundaries
§ 27-301 DISTRICTS.
   For the purpose of this chapter, the borough is hereby divided into
districts which shall be designated as follows:
 
C Conservation District
R-S Residential-Suburban District
R-U Residential-Urban District
T-C Town Center District
C-H Commercial-Highway District
M-C Manufacturing-Commercial District
P-C Planned Commercial District
 
(Ord. 171, passed 1-18-1972, Art. III, § 301; Ord. 1997-04, passed 3-18-1997)
§ 27-302 ZONING MAP.
   The boundaries of said districts shall be as shown upon the map designated
“Zoning Map - Borough of Dillsburg”. The said map, and all the notations,
references and other data shown thereon, are hereby incorporated by reference
into this chapter as if all were fully described herein.
(Ord. 171, passed 1-18-1972, Art. III, § 302; Ord. 212, passed 2-20-1979; Ord.
1982-1, passed 3-16-1982; Ord. 1997-04, passed 3-18-1997)
§ 27-303 DISTRICT BOUNDARIES.
   Where uncertainty exists as to boundaries of any district as shown on said
map, the following rules shall apply.
   (A)   District boundary lines are intended to follow or be parallel to the
centerline of streets, streams and railroads and to lot or property lines as
they exist on plans of record at the time of the adoption of this chapter,
unless such district boundary lines are fixed by dimensions as shown on the
zoning map.
   (B)   Where a district boundary is not fixed by dimensions and where it
approximately follows lot lines, or approved subdivision plans, and where it
does not scale more than ten feet therefrom, such lot lines shall be construed
to be such boundaries unless specifically shown otherwise.
   (C)   In unsubdivided land or where a district boundary divides a lot, the
location of such boundary, unless the same is indicated by dimensions, shall be
determined by the use of the scale appearing on the map.
(Ord. 171, passed 1-18-1972, Art. III, § 303; Ord. 1997-04, passed 3-18-1997)
§ 27-304 INTERPRETATION OF BOUNDARIES.
   In case of an uncertainty, the Zoning Hearing Board shall interpret the
intent of the map as to location of district boundaries.
(Ord. 171, passed 1-18-1972, Art. III, § 304; Ord. 1997-04, passed 3-18-1997)
§ 27-305 USE ADJUSTMENT ON DISTRICT BOUNDARIES.
   In subdivided land where a district boundary line divides a lot held in
single and separate ownership the regulations of a district may extend over
either portion of the lot a distance of not more than 50 feet beyond the
district boundary line providing such extension does not extend the district
boundary along a street or road.
(Ord. 171, passed 1-18-1972, Art. III, § 305; Ord. 1997-04, passed 3-18-1997)
PART 4: DISTRICT REGULATIONS
A: C - CONSERVATION DISTRICT
Section
   
27-401   District purpose
   
27-402   Basic use regulations
   
27-403   Basic spatial regulations
§ 27-401 DISTRICT PURPOSE.
   To conserve those areas predominated by steep slopes; to protect essential
watershed, stream valley and floodplain areas; to ensure open space necessary
to the health, safety and welfare of the citizens; and to permit development
and activities compatible and appropriate thereto.
(Ord. 171, passed 1-18-1972, Art. IV, § 401; Ord. 1997-04, passed 3-18-1997)
§ 27-402 BASIC USE REGULATIONS.
   In this district, buildings, structures and lots shall be subject to the
following basic use regulations.
   (A)   Uses by right. The following uses, limited to one principal use per
lot, are permitted by right in the C District:
      (1)   Agriculture;
      (2)   Bed and breakfast inn;
      (3)   Family day care home;
      (4)   Forest reserves;
      (5)   Greenhouse, horticultural nursery;
      (6)   Group home;
      (7)   Home occupation;
      (8)   Neighborhood park or playground;
      (9)   Public conservation areas and structures for the conservation of
open space, water, soil and wildlife resources;
      (10)   Sale of agricultural products raised or produced on the premises;
      (11)   Signs, as permitted by and subject to the related regulations of
this chapter;
      (12)   Single-family detached dwelling;
      (13)   Accessory structures and uses associated with, but incidental to,
the above uses; and
      (14)   No-impact home-based business.
   (B)   Uses by special exception. The following uses, limited to one
principal use per lot, shall be permitted as special exceptions when authorized
by the Zoning Hearing Board in accordance with the requirements of this
chapter:
      (1)   Communication transmitting and receiving facility;
      (2)   Half-way house;
      (3)   Kennel;
      (4)   Public/semi-public buildings and facilities;
      (5)   Public/semi-public utility building or service structure; and
      (6)   Accessory structures and uses associated with, but incidental to,
the above uses.
(Ord. 171, passed 1-18-1972, Art. IV, § 402; Ord. 1993-2, passed 2-16-1993;
Ord. 1997-04, passed 3-18-1997)
§ 27-403 BASIC SPATIAL REGULATIONS.
   In this district, all buildings, structures and lots shall be subject to the
following basic spatial related regulations which shall be considered minimum
standards.
   (A)   Lot requirements.
      (1)   Area. The lot area and lot area per dwelling unit shall be not less
than one acre.
      (2)   Width. The lot width at the front setback line shall be not less
than 200 feet.
   (B)   Setback requirements. Each lot shall have front, side and rear
setbacks of not less than the depth and width indicated below:
      (1)   Front setback - depth. Fifty feet;
      (2)   Side setback - width. Thirty feet each; and
      (3)   Rear setback - depth. Fifty feet.
   (C)   Lot coverage.
      (1)   The lot coverage by all buildings and structures shall be not
greater than 15%.
      (2)   At least 50% of the lot shall be wooded or permanently planted with
trees and shrubs.
   (D)   Building height. No limit.
   (E)   Off-street parking and loading. Off-street parking, loading and
unloading areas shall be provided in accordance with the related regulations of
this chapter.
   (F)   Decorative canopies. Whenever an existing building has no front
setback, the owner thereof shall be authorized to construct a decorative canopy
above the first floor, provided that the canopy shall not extend more than 24
inches over the sidewalk and shall have a height at its lowest point of at
least eight feet ten inches. Whenever a decorative canopy is to be constructed
on any building which will not extend more than 36 inches beyond such building,
such canopy shall not be considered as part of the building for the purpose of
determining the depth of a front setback.
   (G)   Performance standards. All residential commercial, and industrial uses
shall comply with the performance standards set forth in §
27-509 of this chapter. Residential performance standards deal with density and
lot coverage requirements, while commercial and industrial performance
standards deal with lot area and nuisance and hazard abatement requirements.
(Ord. 171, passed 1-18-1972, Art. IV, § 403; Ord. 190, passed 9-16-1975; Ord.
1993-2, passed 2-16-1993; Ord. 1997-04, passed 3-18-1997)
B: R-S - RESIDENTIAL - SUBURBAN DISTRICT
Section
   
27-411   District purpose
   
27-412   Basic use regulations
   
27-413   Basic spatial regulations
§ 27-411 DISTRICT PURPOSE.
   To provide for the orderly expansion of typical suburban residential
development; to authorize conditional or supplemental uses incidental with
suburban living; to assure the efficient use of land available for such
development within the borough; and to provide for the orderly development of
those uses desirable to meet the community needs for such conditional or
supplemental uses, as well as those of a social, cultural and civic nature; but
to exclude purely commercial or industrial activities incompatible with
suburban residential living.
(Ord. 171, passed 1-18-1972, Art. IV, § 411; Ord. 213, passed 3-29-1979; Ord.
1997-04, passed 3-18-1997)
§ 27-412 BASIC USE REGULATIONS.
   In this district, buildings, structures and lots shall be subject to the
following basic use regulations.
   (A)   Uses by right. The following uses, limited to one principal use per
lot, are permitted by right in the R-S District:
      (1)   Bed and breakfast inn;
      (2)   Crops and gardening;
      (3)   Domiciliary care home;
      (4)   Family day care home;
      (5)   Group home;
      (6)   Public/semi-public buildings and facilities;
      (7)   Public/semi-public utility building or service structure;
      (8)   Signs, as permitted by and subject to the requirements of this
chapter;
      (9)   Single-family dwelling (attached, detached, or semi-detached);
      (10)   Two-family dwelling (a single-family dwelling cannot be converted
into a two-family dwelling);
      (11)   Accessory structures and uses associated with, but incidental to,
the above uses, excluding home occupations; and
      (12)   No-impact home-based business.
   (B)   Conditional uses. The following uses, limited to one principal use per
lot except as otherwise permitted by this chapter, shall be permitted as
conditional uses in the R-S District when authorized by the Planning Commission
and Borough Council, subject to the additional requirements set forth below:
      (1)   Mobile home park (mobile home lots within the mobile home park
shall comply with the requirements for single-family detached dwellings);
      (2)   Multi-family dwellings in combination with a professional/business
office complex, constructed on a lot with a minimum gross area of one acre or
in accordance with the lot area requirements of §
27-413(A)(1)(d), whichever is greater; and
      (3)   Professional/business office complex, constructed on a lot with a
minimum gross area of one acre or in accordance with the lot area requirements
of §
27-413(A)(1)(d), whichever is greater.
   (C)   Additional requirements for conditional uses. The following shall be
considered by the Planning Commission and Borough Council in addition to any
other requirements set forth in the zoning ordinance or the subdivision and
land development ordinance (Chapter 22 of this code of ordinances).
      (1)   There shall be determined that there is a need for the use in the
area proposed, or that there is a need within the borough for such use and
other space is unavailable in other zones.
      (2)   There shall be determined that there is sufficient area to
effectively screen the conditional use from adjacent or nearby differing uses.
      (3)   There shall be as part of the requirements under the land
development article, sufficient safeguard for parking, traffic control,
screening and setbacks that can be implemented to remove any potential adverse
influence the use may have on adjoining or nearby uses.
      (4)   There shall be requirements for architectural and aesthetic
blending with surrounding improved areas or potential uses of surrounding
areas.
   (D)   Uses by special exception. The following uses, limited to one
principal use per lot, shall be permitted as special exceptions in the R-
S District when authorized by the Zoning Hearing Board in accordance with the
requirements of this chapter:
      (1)   Cemetery;
      (2)   Convalescent or nursing home;
      (3)   Funeral home, mortuary;
      (4)   Group day care home;
      (5)   Home occupation;
      (6)   Hospital;
      (7)   House of worship;
      (8)   Medical clinic;
      (9)   Multi-family dwelling(s) (a single-family or two-family dwelling
cannot be converted into a multi-family dwelling);
      (10)   Neighborhood park or playground;
      (11)   School; and
      (12)   Accessory structures and uses associated with, but incidental to,
the above uses.
   (E)   Prohibited use. There shall be no retail sales establishments
conducted within the R-S District, except as otherwise may be permitted as a
home occupation.
(Ord. 171, passed 1-18-1972, Art. IV, § 412; Ord. 213, passed 3-29-1979; Ord.
1993-2, passed 2-16-1993; Ord. 1997-04, passed 3-18-1997)
§ 27-413 BASIC SPATIAL REGULATIONS.
   In this district, all buildings, structures, and lots shall be subject to
the following spatial related regulations which shall be considered as minimum
standards.
   (A)   Lot requirements.
      (1)   Area. Lot area, not less than the following, shall be provided for
each principal use hereafter established in this district, unless otherwise
required by this chapter.
         (a)   Single-family detached dwelling. Ten thousand square feet per
dwelling unit;
         (b)   Single-family attached dwelling. Two thousand square feet per
dwelling unit;
         (c)   Single-family semi-detached or two-family dwelling. Six thousand
square feet per dwelling unit;
         (d)   Multi-family dwelling(s) and/or professional/business office
complex. Each individual dwelling unit or office of which shall be considered a
unit:
            1.   One-story. Two thousand square feet per unit;
            2.   Two- to three-story. One thousand five hundred square feet per
unit; and
            3.   More than three-story. One thousand square feet per unit.
         (e)   All other uses. Ten thousand square feet.
      (2)   Width. Lot width not less than the following shall be provided for
each principal use hereafter established in this district, unless otherwise
required by this chapter. The lot width at the front setback line shall be not
less than:
         (a)   Sixty-five feet with lot area less than 10,000 square feet,
except in the case of single-family attached dwellings which shall have a
minimum lot width of 20 feet;
         (b)   Eighty feet with lot area at least 10,000 square feet but less
than 20,000 square feet; and
         (c)   One hundred feet with lot area of 20,000 square feet or greater.
   (B)   Setback requirements. Each lot shall have front, side and rear
setbacks of not less than the depth and width indicated below:
      (1)   Front setback - depth. Thirty feet;
      (2)   Side setback - width. Fifteen feet each (may be reduced to 12 feet
in the case of a single-family dwelling on a lot having a width of not more
than 90 feet); a single-family semi-detached dwelling shall have only one side
setback and, in the case of single-family attached dwellings, only the end
units shall have a side setback; and
      (3)   Rear setback - depth. Thirty feet.
   (C)   Lot coverage. The lot coverage by all buildings and structures shall
be not greater than 30%.
   (D)   Building height. No building shall be erected to a height in excess of
35 feet.
   (E)   Off-street parking and loading. Off-street parking, loading and
unloading areas shall be provided in accordance with the related regulations of
this chapter.
   (F)   Decorative canopies. Whenever an existing building has no front
setback, the owner thereof shall be authorized to construct a decorative canopy
above the first floor, provided that the canopy shall not extend more than 24
inches over the sidewalk and shall have a height at its lowest point of at
least eight feet ten inches. Whenever a decorative canopy is to be constructed
on any building which will not extend more than 36 inches beyond such building,
such canopy shall not be considered as part of the building for the purpose of
determining the depth of a front setback.
   (G)   Performance standards. All residential, commercial, and industrial
uses shall comply with the performance standards set forth in §
27-509 of this chapter. Residential performance standards deal with density and
lot coverage requirements, while commercial and industrial performance
standards deal with lot area and nuisance and hazard abatement requirements.
(Ord. 171, passed 1-18-1972, Art. IV, § 413; Ord. 190, passed 9-16-1975; Ord.
213, passed 3-29-1979; Ord. 1997-04, passed 3-18-1997)
C: R-U - RESIDENTIAL - URBAN DISTRICT
Section
   
27-421   District purpose
   
27-422   Basic use regulations
   
27-423   Basic spatial regulations
§ 27-421 DISTRICT PURPOSE.
   To provide for the preservation and orderly redevelopment of existing
residential areas where adequate public services and facilities are essential
for the health, safety and general welfare of the population are available; to
prevent the overcrowding of land through the application of maximum housing
densities; to provide for the public convenience and avoid undue congestion of
the streets; to exclude activities of a commercial, industrial or other nature
not compatible with the residential environment; and to otherwise create
conditions conducive to carrying out the purpose of this chapter.
(Ord. 171, passed 1-18-1972, Art. IV, § 421; Ord. 1997-04, passed 3-18-1997)
§ 27-422 BASIC USE REGULATIONS.
   In this district, buildings, structures and lots shall be subject to the
following basic use regulations.
   (A)   Uses by right. The following uses, limited to one principal use per
lot, are permitted by right in the R-U District:
      (1)   Cemetery;
      (2)   Crops and gardening;
      (3)   Family day care home;
      (4)   Group home;
      (5)   Home occupation;
      (6)   House of worship;
      (7)   Medical clinic;
      (8)   Multi-family dwelling(s) of three or less stories (a single-family
or two-family dwelling cannot be converted into a multi-family dwelling);
      (9)   Neighborhood park or playground;
      (10)   Public/semi-public buildings and facilities;
      (11)   Public/semi-public utility building or service structure;
      (12)   School;
      (13)   Signs, as permitted by and subject to the requirements of this
chapter;
      (14)   Single-family dwelling (attached, detached, and semi-detached);
      (15)   Two-family dwelling or two-family conversion dwelling;
      (16)   Accessory uses and structures associated with, but incidental to,
the above uses; and
      (17)   No-impact home-based business.
   (B)   Uses by special exception. The following uses, limited to one
principal use per lot except as otherwise permitted by this chapter, shall be
permitted as special exceptions in the R-U District when authorized by the
Zoning Hearing Board in accordance with the requirements of this chapter:
      (1)   Bed and breakfast inn;
      (2)   Boarding house, rooming house;
      (3)   Clubs and lodges of a fraternal nature;
      (4)   Convalescent or nursing home;
      (5)   Domiciliary care home;
      (6)   Dwelling unit(s) in combination with a professional office or
business office;
      (7)   Funeral home, mortuary;
      (8)   Group day care home;
      (9)   Group quarters;
      (10)   Hospital;
      (11)   Multi-family dwelling(s) greater than three stories in height (a
single-family or two-family dwelling cannot be converted into a multi-family
dwelling);
      (12)   Personal service business in combination with a multi-family
dwelling, provided that the business is located on the first floor and/or
basement level of the building;
      (13)   Professional office, business office;
      (14)   Public/semi-public parking lot or garage; and
      (15)   Accessory structures and uses associated with, but incidental to,
the above uses.
(Ord. 171, passed 1-18-1972, Art. IV, § 422; Ord. 1981-1, passed 2-17-1981;
Ord. 1997-04, passed 3-18-1997)
§ 27-423 BASIC SPATIAL REGULATIONS.
   In this district, all buildings, structures and lots shall be subject to the
following basic spatial related regulations which shall be considered as
minimum standards:
   (A)   Lot area requirement. Lot area, not less than the following, shall be
provided for each principal use hereafter established in this district, unless
otherwise required by this chapter.
      (1)   Single-family detached dwelling. Six thousand square feet per
dwelling unit;
      (2)   Single-family attached dwelling. One thousand eight hundred square
feet per dwelling unit;
      (3)   Single-family semi-detached or two-family dwelling. Three thousand
square feet per dwelling unit;
      (4)   Multi-family dwellings and two-family conversion dwellings. Shall
have a lot area per dwelling unit which shall be not less than the following:
         (a)   One-story. Two thousand square feet per dwelling unit;
         (b)   Two-story. One thousand five hundred square feet per dwelling
unit;
         (c)   Three story. One thousand five hundred square feet per dwelling
unit; and
         (d)   More than three-story. One thousand square feet per dwelling
unit.
      (5)   Professional or business office. When considering lot area
requirements for a professional or business office, each individual office in
the same structure shall be considered as a single-family detached dwelling
unit; and
      (6)   All other uses. Six thousand square feet.
   (B)   Setback requirements. Each lot shall have front, side and rear
setbacks of not less than the depth and width indicated below:
      (1)   Front setback - depth. Twenty-five feet;
      (2)   Side setback - width. Ten feet each, a single-family semi-detached
dwelling shall have only one side setback and, in the case of single-family
attached dwellings, only the end units shall have a side setback; and
      (3)   Rear setback - depth. Twenty feet.
   (C)   Lot coverage. The lot coverage by all building and structures shall
not be greater than 40%.
   (D)   Building height. No building, excluding multi-family dwellings as a
special exception, shall be extended to a height in excess of 35 feet.
   (E)   Off-street parking and loading.
      (1)   Generally. Off-street parking, loading and unloading areas shall be
provided in accordance with the related regulations of this chapter.
      (2)   Professional office parking.
         (a)   At least two off-street parking spaces for each 300 square feet
of floor area or fraction thereof utilized for professional or business offices
shall be provided in addition to the off-street parking as may be required for
multi-family dwelling units combined with such professional or business offices
in accordance with the related regulations of this chapter.
         (b)   If it be determined by the Zoning Officer that the professional
office parking requirements in subsection (E)(2)(a) above are insufficient,
prior to issuing a zoning permit, the Zoning Officer may require that there be
one parking space for each professional utilizing such office space plus one
parking space for each employee or associate plus one parking space for each 21
square feet of area contained in the reception room, waiting room, examination
room or conference room area.
   (F)   Decorative canopies. Whenever an existing building has no front
setback, the owner thereof shall be authorized to construct a decorative canopy
above the first floor, provided that the canopy shall not extend more than 24
inches over the sidewalk and shall have a height at its lowest point of at
least eight feet ten inches. Whenever a decorative canopy is to be constructed
on any building which will not extend more than 36 inches beyond such building,
such canopy shall not be considered as part of the building for the purpose of
determining the depth of a front setback.
   (G)   Performance standards. All residential, commercial and industrial uses
shall comply with the performance standards set forth in §
27-509 of this chapter. Residential performance standards deal with density and
lot coverage requirements, while commercial and industrial performance
standards deal with lot area and nuisance and hazard abatement requirements.
(Ord. 171, passed 1-18-1972, Art. IV, § 423; Ord. 190, passed 9-16-1975; Ord.
1981-1, passed 2-17-1981; Ord. 1997-04, passed 3-18-1997)
D: T-C - TOWN CENTER DISTRICT
Section
   
27-431   District purpose
   
27-432   Basic use regulations
   
27-433   Basic spatial regulations
§ 27-431 DISTRICT PURPOSE.
   To provide for the continued development of community centers typical of
towns and village settlements common to rural and semi-rural areas in an
orderly manner; to exclude uses which would not be compatible with such areas;
and to otherwise create conditions conducive to carrying out the purposes of
this chapter.
(Ord. 171, passed 1-18-1972, Art. IV, § 431; Ord. 1997-04, passed 3-18-1997)
§ 27-432 BASIC USE REGULATIONS.
   In this district, buildings, structures and lots shall be subject to the
basic use regulations set forth in this section. No use permitted in the T-
C District, whether by right or by special exception, shall include the sale of
alcoholic beverages intended for consumption either on- or off-premises.
   (A)   Uses by right. The following uses, limited to one principal use per
lot, are permitted by right in the T-C District:
      (1)   Adult or child day care center, nursery school;
      (2)   Bed and breakfast inn;
      (3)   Boarding house, rooming house;
      (4)   Commercial school;
      (5)   Domiciliary care home;
      (6)   Eating establishment;
      (7)   Family day care home;
      (8)   Funeral home, mortuary;
      (9)   Group home;
      (10)   Group quarters;
      (11)   Home occupation;
      (12)   Hotel or motel;
      (13)   House of worship;
      (14)   Medical clinic;
      (15)   Multi-family or two-family conversion dwelling, not exceeding
three dwelling units;
      (16)   Multi-family dwelling, not exceeding four dwelling units (a
single-family or two-family dwelling cannot be converted into a four unit
multi-family dwelling);
      (17)   Neighborhood park or playground;
      (18)   Personal service business;
      (19)   Professional office, business office;
      (20)   Professional/business office complex;
      (21)   Public/semi-public buildings and facilities;
      (22)   Public/semi-public parking lot or garage;
      (23)   Public/semi-public utility buildings and service structures;
      (24)   Retail store or shop;
      (25)   School;
      (26)   Signs, as permitted by and subject to the requirements of this
chapter;
      (27)   Single-family dwelling (attached, detached, and semi-detached);
      (28)   Two-family dwelling; and
      (29)   Accessory structures and uses associated with, but incidental to,
the above uses.
   (B)   Uses by special exception. The following uses, limited to one
principal use per lot, shall be permitted as special exceptions in the T-
C District when authorized by the Zoning Hearing Board in accordance with the
requirements of this chapter:
      (1)   Clubs and lodges of a fraternal nature;
      (2)   Commercial parking lot or garage;
      (3)   Indoor commercial recreation establishment;
      (4)   Multi-family conversion dwelling, exceeding three dwelling units;
      (5)   Multi-family dwellings, exceeding four dwelling units;
      (6)   Personal care boarding home;
      (7)   Service station or convenience store dispensing fuel (see §
27-514); and
      (8)   Accessory structures and uses associated with, but incidental to,
the above uses.
   (C)   Multi-use building. Two or more individual uses permitted in the T-
C District, whether permitted by right or by special exception, may be
established within a single building provided that the regulations established
in this chapter for each individual use are satisfied, e.g., parking, special
exception approval. The principal building itself, however, shall be considered
as a unit for purposes of lot area and setback requirements; such provisions
shall not be cumulative for the individual uses established.
(Ord. 171, passed 1-18-1972, Art. IV, § 432; Ord. 1997-04, passed 3-18-1997)
§ 27-433 BASIC SPATIAL REGULATIONS.
   In this district, all buildings, structures and lots shall be subject to the
following basic spatial related regulations which shall be considered as
minimum standards:
   (A)   Lot area requirements. Lot area not less than the following shall be
provided for each principal use hereafter established in the T-C District,
unless otherwise required by this chapter:
      (1)   Single-family detached dwelling. Four thousand five hundred square
feet per dwelling unit;
      (2)   Single-family attached dwelling. One thousand eight hundred square
feet per dwelling unit;
      (3)   Single-family semi-detached or two-family dwelling. Three thousand
square feet per dwelling unit;
      (4)   Multi-family dwellings, and multi-family or two-family conversions
dwellings. Shall have a lot area per dwelling unit which shall be not less than
the following:
         (a)   One-story. Two thousand square feet per dwelling unit;
         (b)   Two-story. One thousand five hundred square feet per dwelling
unit;
         (c)   Three-story. One thousand five hundred square feet per dwelling
unit; and
         (d)   More than three-story. One thousand square feet per dwelling
unit.
      (5)   All other uses. Four thousand five hundred square feet.
   (B)   Setback requirements. Each lot shall have front, side, and rear
setbacks of not less than the depth and width indicated below:
      (1)   Front setback - depth. Ten feet. (The reduction of the required
front yard to conform to existing building lines provision of the general
regulations of this chapter shall not be permitted south of York Street nor
north of Church Street);
      (2)   Side setback - width. Five feet each; provided that when mutual
agreement is provided in writing by the adjoining property owners, no side
setback shall be required where two or more commercial uses adjoin side to
side; however, in no case shall common walls be permitted between properties of
separate ownership. In the case of a series of adjoining structures abutting
and paralleling a public right-of-way, an unobstructed passage of at least 20
feet in width shall be provided at grade level at intervals not more than 400
feet apart. (A single-family semi-detached dwelling shall have only one side
setback and, in the case of single-family attached dwellings, only the end
units shall have a side setback);
      (3)   Rear setback - depth. Twenty feet; and
      (4)   Special buffering. Except in the case of multi-family dwellings,
the Zoning Hearing Board may require additional setbacks and screen planting as
deemed necessary to adequately buffer uses permitted as special exceptions when
such would abut residential properties or districts.
   (C)   Lot coverage. The lot coverage by all buildings and structures shall
not be greater than 50%.
   (D)   Building height. No building shall be extended to a height in excess
of 50 feet.
   (E)   Off-street parking and loading. Off-street parking, loading and
unloading areas shall be provided in accordance with the related regulations of
this chapter.
   (F)   Decorative canopies. Whenever an existing building has no front
setback, the owner thereof shall be authorized to construct a decorative canopy
above the first floor, provided that the canopy shall not extend more than 24
inches over the sidewalk and shall have a height at its lowest point of at
least eight feet ten inches. Whenever a decorative canopy is to be constructed
on any building which will not extend more than 36 inches beyond such building,
such canopy shall not be considered as part of the building for the purpose of
determining the depth of a front setback.
   (G)   Performance standards. All residential, commercial and industrial uses
shall comply with the performance standards set forth in §
27-509 of this chapter. Residential performance standards deal with density and
lot coverage requirements, while commercial and industrial performance
standards deal with lot area and nuisance and hazard abatement requirements.
(Ord. 171, passed 1-18-1972, Art. IV, § 433; Ord. 190, passed 9-16-1975; Ord.
1997-04, passed 3-18-1997)
E: C-H - COMMERCIAL - HIGHWAY DISTRICT
Section
   
27-441   District purpose
   
27-442   Basic use regulations
   
27-443   Basic spatial regulations
§ 27-441 DISTRICT PURPOSE.
   To provide reasonable standards for the development of highway-oriented
commercial uses along the roadside in areas where such uses already exist and
where, due to the character of undeveloped land, the development of highway
commercial uses is feasible and appropriate. The standards of this district are
designed to separate access roads from major thoroughfares, to minimize traffic
congestion, and to protect adjoining residential districts.
(Ord. 171, passed 1-18-1972, Art. IV, § 441; Ord. 1997-04, passed 3-18-1997)
§ 27-442 BASIC USE REGULATIONS.
   In this district, buildings, structures and lots shall be subject to the
basic use regulations listed below. In addition, within this district,
alcoholic beverages may only be sold for on- or off-premises consumption in
conjunction with an eating establishment, hotel or motel, adult cabaret, or
tavern. The selling of alcoholic beverages in conjunction with any other use
shall require special exception approval by the Zoning Hearing Board.
   (A)   Uses by right. The following uses, limited to one principal use per
lot, are permitted by right in the C-H District:
      (1)   Adult or child day care center;
      (2)   Adult regulated facility;
      (3)   Animal hospital, kennel;
      (4)   Commercial recreation establishment (indoor or outdoor);
      (5)   Contractor’s office or shop;
      (6)   Eating establishment;
      (7)   Hotel or motel;
      (8)   Medical clinic;
      (9)   Mini-storage facility;
      (10)   Mobile home sales lot;
      (11)   Personal service business;
      (12)   Professional office, business office;
      (13)   Professional/business office complex;
      (14)   Public, semi-public or commercial parking lot or garage;
      (15)   Public/semi-public utility building or service structure;
      (16)   Retail store or shop;
      (17)   Service station or convenience store dispensing fuel (see §
27-514);
      (18)   Shopping center or mall;
      (19)   Signs as permitted by and subject to the requirements of this
chapter;
      (20)   Small processing establishment;
      (21)   Tavern;
      (22)   Vehicle sales, rental, service and/or repair facility;
      (23)   Vehicle washing facility;
      (24)   Accessory structures and uses associated with, but incidental to,
the above uses;
      (25)   Medical marijuana dispensary, subject to the following specific
standards.
         (a)   A medical marijuana dispensary must be legally registered in the
Commonwealth and possess a current valid medical marijuana permit from the
Pennsylvania Department of Health.
         (b)   A medical marijuana dispensary may only dispense medical
marijuana in an indoor, enclosed, permanent and secure building and shall not
be located in a trailer, cargo container, mobile or modular unit, mobile home,
recreational vehicle or other motor vehicle.
         (c)   A medical marijuana dispensary may not operate on the same site
as a facility used for growing and processing medical marijuana.
         (d)   Medical marijuana dispensaries shall have a single secure public
entrance and shall implement appropriate security measures to deter and prevent
the theft of marijuana and unauthorized entrance into areas containing medical
marijuana.
         (e)   A medical marijuana dispensary shall:
            1.   Not have a drive-in service;
            2.   Not have an outdoor seating area;
            3.   Not have an outdoor vending area;
            4.   Prohibit the administering of, or the consumption of medical
marijuana on the premises; and
            5.   Not offer direct or home delivery service.
         (f)   A medical marijuana dispensary may dispense only medical
marijuana to certified patients and caregivers and shall comply with all
lawful, applicable health regulations.
         (g)   The medical marijuana dispensary may not be located within 1,000
feet of the property line of an educational institution or a day care center.
This distance shall be measured in a straight line from the closest exterior
wall of the building or portion thereof in which the business is conducted or
proposed to be conducted, to the closest property line of the protected use,
regardless of municipality in which it is located.
         (h)   Any medical marijuana facility lawfully operating shall not be
rendered in violation of these provisions by the subsequent location of any
uses referenced in subsection (A)(25)(g) above.
         (i)   Off-street parking and loading: off-street parking, loading and
unloading areas shall be provided in accordance with the related regulations of
the code. All loading and off-loading areas shall be within secure
environments.
         (j)   All external lighting shall comply with the code.
      (26)   Medical marijuana grower/processor, subject to the following
specific standards.
         (a)   A medical marijuana grower/processor may only grow medical
marijuana in an indoor, enclosed and secure building which includes electronic
locking system, electronic surveillance and other features required by the
Department of Health. The grower/processor facility shall not be located in a
trailer, cargo container, mobile or modular unit, mobile home, recreation
vehicle or other motor vehicle.
         (b)   The floor area of a medical marijuana grower/processor shall
include sufficient space for production, secure storage of marijuana seeds,
related finished product cultivation and marijuana related material used in
production and cultivation or for required laboratory testing.
         (c)   There shall be no emission of dust, fumes, vapors, odors or
waste into the environment from any facility where medical marijuana growing,
processing or testing occurs.
         (d)   Marijuana remnants and by-products shall be secured and properly
disposed of in accordance with Department of Health policy and shall not be
placed within any unsecured exterior refuse containers.
         (e)   The grower/processor shall provide only wholesale products to
other medical marijuana facilities. Retail sales and dispensing of medical
marijuana and related products is prohibited at medical marijuana grower/
processor facilities.
         (f)   The medical marijuana grower/processor may not be located within
1,000 feet of the property line of an educational institution or a day care
center. This distance shall be measured in a straight line from the closest
exterior wall of the building or portion thereof in which the business is
conducted or proposed to be conducted, to the closest property line of the
protected use, regardless of municipality in which it is located.
         (g)   Any medical marijuana grower/processor lawfully operating shall
not be rendered in violation of these provisions by the subsequent location of
any uses referenced in subsection (A)(26)(f).
         (h)   Off-street parking and loading: off-street parking, loading and
unloading areas shall be provided in accordance with the related regulations of
the code. All loading and off-loading areas shall be within secure
environments.
         (i)   All external lighting shall comply with the code.
(Ord. 171, passed 1-18-1972, Art. IV, § 442; Ord. 1997-04, passed 3-18-1997;
Ord. 2022-1, passed 12-13-2022)
§ 27-443 BASIC SPATIAL REGULATIONS.
   In this district, all buildings, structures, and lots shall be subject to
the following basic spatial related regulations which shall be considered as
minimum standards.
   (A)   Lot area requirements. None.
   (B)   Setback requirements. Each lot shall have front, side and rear
setbacks of not less than the depth and width indicated below:
      (1)   Front setback - depth. Fifty feet;
      (2)   Side setback - width. Ten feet when abutting a public service
drive, 20 feet elsewhere, provided that when a mutual agreement is provided in
writing by the adjoining property owners, no side setback shall be required
where two or more commercial uses adjoin side to side; however, in no case
shall common walls be permitted between properties of separated ownership. In
the case of a series of adjoining structures abutting and paralleling a public
right-of-way, an unobstructed passage of at least 20 feet in width shall be
provided at grade level at intervals not more than 400 feet apart;
      (3)   Rear setback - depth. Thirty feet; and
      (4)   Buffer yards. Buffer yards required (may include required setback
area):
         (a)   Where abutting a residential district, a buffer yard of not less
then 25 feet shall be required;
         (b)   Where abutting a stream, a buffer yard of not less than 15 feet
in width, measured from the edge of the stream shall be required;
         (c)   All of the foregoing buffer yards shall be planted and
maintained with a vegetative material to include a row of evergreen screen
planting; and
         (d)   Buffer yards other than interior side or rear buffer yards may
be crossed by access roads and services drives not more than 35 feet in width.
   (C)   Lot coverage.
      (1)   The lot coverage by all buildings and structures shall not be
greater than 30%.
      (2)   Not less than 10% of the lot area shall be covered with a
vegetative material.
   (D)   Building height. No building or structure shall be erected to a height
in excess of 35 feet.
   (E)   Off-street parking and loading. Off-street parking, loading and
unloading areas shall be provided in accordance with the related regulations of
this chapter.
   (F)   Decorative canopies. Whenever an existing building has no front
setback, the owner thereof shall be authorized to construct a decorative canopy
above the first floor, provided that the canopy shall not extend more than 24
inches over the sidewalk and shall have a height at its lowest point of at
least eight feet ten inches. Whenever a decorative canopy is to be constructed
on any building which will not extend more than 36 inches beyond such building,
such canopy shall not be considered as part of the building for the purpose of
determining the depth of a front setback.
   (G)   Performance standards. All residential, commercial and industrial uses
shall comply with the performance standards set forth in §
27-509 of this chapter. Residential performance standards deal with density and
lot coverage requirements, while commercial and industrial performance
standards deal with lot area and nuisance and hazard abatement requirements.
(Ord. 171, passed 1-18-1972, Art. IV, § 443; Ord. 190, passed 9-16-1975; Ord.
1997-04, passed 3-18-1997)
F: M-C - MANUFACTURING - COMMERCIAL DISTRICT
Section
   
27-451   District purpose
   
27-452   Basic use regulations
   
27-453   Basic spatial regulations
§ 27-451 DISTRICT PURPOSE.
   To provide for the expansion and orderly development of uses of a light
industrial and heavy commercial nature where such uses already exist and where
such are appropriate to the character of the area; to minimize traffic
congestion; to exclude uses not appropriate to such areas; to protect adjacent
residential uses; and to otherwise create conditions conducive to carrying out
the purposes of this chapter.
(Ord. 171, passed 1-18-1972, Art. IV, § 451; Ord. 1997-04, passed 3-18-1997)
§ 27-452 BASIC USE REGULATIONS.
   In this district, buildings, structures and lots shall be subject to the
following basic use regulations.
   (A)   Uses by right. The following uses, limited to one principal use per
lot, are permitted by right in the M-C District:
      (1)   Adult or child day care center;
      (2)   Agricultural equipment sales, service, and/or repair facility;
      (3)   Contractor’s office or shop;
      (4)   Fuel storage and supply;
      (5)   Heavy storage sales and/or service facility; e.g., warehouse,
building material yard, construction equipment and commercial vehicles;
      (6)   Industrial activities;
      (7)   Industrial or business park;
      (8)   Mini-storage facility;
      (9)   Professional office, business office;
      (10)   Professional/business office complex;
      (11)   Public semi-public, or commercial parking lot or garage;
      (12)   Public buildings and facilities;
      (13)   Public utility building or service structure;
      (14)   Research laboratory;
      (15)   Signs, as permitted by and subject to the requirements of this
chapter;
      (16)   Wholesale establishment; and
      (17)   Accessory structures and uses associated with, but incidental to,
the above uses.
   (B)   Conditional uses.
      (1)   The following use, limited to one principal use per lot except as
otherwise permitted by this chapter, shall be permitted as a conditional use in
the M-C District, when authorized by the Planning Commission and Borough
Council:
      (2)   Junkyard, subject to the following specific standards.
         (a)   No material shall be placed in any junkyard in such a manner
that it is capable of being transferred out of the junkyard by wind, water or
other natural causes.
         (b)   All paper, rags, cloth and other fibers shall be stored, and all
activities involving the same, except loading and unloading, shall be
conducted, within a fully enclosed building.
         (c)   All junkyard materials and activities not within a fully
enclosed building shall be surrounded by an eight-foot high sight-tight
(opaque) fence and maintained in good condition. Any gate in such fence shall
be similarly constructed and maintained and must be kept locked at all times
when the junkyard is not in operation.
         (d)   The storage of hazardous materials is prohibited.
         (e)   No junkyard materials may be stored or stacked higher than eight
feet, provided however that no such materials are visible from adjoining
properties and roads.
         (f)   All junkyard materials shall be stored in such a manner as to
prevent the breeding or harboring of rats, insects or other vermin, as well as
to prevent fire hazards.
(Ord. 171, passed 1-18-1972, Art. IV, § 452; Ord. 1997-04, passed 3-18-1997)
§ 27-453 BASIC SPATIAL REGULATIONS.
   In this district, all buildings, structures, and lots shall be subject to
the following basic spatial regulations which shall be considered as minimum
standard.
   (A)   Lot area requirements. None.
   (B)   Setback requirements. Each lot shall have front, side and rear
setbacks of not less than the depth and width indicated below:
      (1)   Front setback - depth. Ten feet;
      (2)   Side setback - width. Ten feet when abutting a public service
drive, 20 feet elsewhere, provided that when a mutual agreement is provided in
writing by the adjoining property owners, no side setback shall be required
where two or more commercial uses adjoin side to side; however, in no case
shall common walls be permitted between properties of separated ownership. In
the case of a series of adjoining structures abutting and paralleling a public
right-of-way, an unobstructed passage of at least 20 feet in width shall be
provided at grade level at intervals not more than 400 feet apart;
      (3)   Rear setback. None, except any required buffer yard; and
      (4)   Buffer yards. Buffer yards required (may include required setback
area):
         (a)   Where abutting a residential district, a buffer yard of not less
then 20 feet shall be required;
         (b)   Where abutting a street that abuts a residential district, a
buffer yard of not less than 15 feet measured from the street line shall be
required;
         (c)   Where abutting a stream, a buffer yard of not less than 15 feet
in width, measured from the edge of the stream shall be required;
         (d)   All of the foregoing buffer yards shall be planted and
maintained with a vegetative material to include a row of evergreen screen
planting; and
         (e)   Buffer yards may be crossed by access drives and service drives
not more than 35 feet in width.
   (C)   Lot coverage. The lot coverage by all buildings and structures shall
not be greater than 50%.
   (D)   Decorative canopies. Whenever an existing building has no front
setback, the owner thereof shall be authorized to construct a decorative canopy
above the first floor, provided that the canopy shall not extend more than 24
inches over the sidewalk and shall have a height at its lowest point of at
least eight feet ten inches. Whenever a decorative canopy is to be constructed
on any building which will not extend more than 36 inches beyond such building,
such canopy shall not be considered as part of the building for the purpose of
determining the depth of a front setback.
   (E)   Performance standards. All residential, commercial and industrial uses
shall comply with the performance standards set forth in §
27-509 of this chapter. Residential performance standards deal with density and
lot coverage requirements, while commercial and industrial performance
standards deal with lot area and nuisance and hazard abatement requirements.
(Ord. 171, passed 1-18-1972, Art. IV, § 453; Ord. 190, passed 9-16-1975; Ord.
1997-04, passed 3-18-1997)
PART G: P-C - PLANNED COMMERCIAL DISTRICT
Section
   
27-461   District purpose
   
27-462   Planned commercial area
   
27-463   Basic use regulations
   
27-464   Basic spatial regulations
§ 27-461 DISTRICT PURPOSE.
   The purpose of the P-C Planned Commercial District is to provide and require
unified and organized arrangement of building service and parking areas,
together with adequate circulation and open space, all planned and designed as
integrated units, in a manner so as to provide and constitute efficient, safe,
convenient and attractive shopping areas.
(Ord. 171, passed 1-18-1972, Art. IV, § 461; Ord. 1986-1, passed 8-12-1986;
Ord. 1997-04, passed 3-18-1997)
§ 27-462 PLANNED COMMERCIAL AREA.
   The zoning map shall be amended by establishing a P-C, Planned Commercial
District, to the west of South Baltimore Street and south of Butler Street,
which district shall be bounded as shown on a plan prepared by Edward E.
Kirkbride, A.R.A., dated April 7, 1986, extending westwardly from South
Baltimore Street a distance of 387 feet, more or less, and extending southward
from Butler Street along South Baltimore Street a distance of 648 feet, more or
less.
(Ord. 171, passed 1-18-1972, Art. IV, § 462; Ord. 1986-1, passed 8-12-1986;
Ord. 1997-04, passed 3-18-1997)
§ 27-463 BASIC USE REGULATIONS.
   (A)   Uses by right. The uses set forth below, limited to one principal use
per lot, are permitted by right in the P-C District. Within this district,
alcoholic beverages shall not be sold for either on- or off-premises
consumption in conjunction with any use.
      (1)   Eating establishment, excluding drive-through facilities;
      (2)   Indoor commercial recreation establishment;
      (3)   Personal service business;
      (4)   Professional office, business office;
      (5)   Professional/business office complex;
      (6)   Public buildings and facilities; and
      (7)   Retail store or shop.
   (B)   Permitted accessory uses/structures located on the same lot with the
permitted principal use.
      (1)   Off-street parking and loading pursuant to §
27-507;
      (2)   Signs pursuant to §
27-511; and
      (3)   Other accessory structures and uses, provided they are associated
with and clearly incidental to the principal use.
(Ord. 171, passed 1-18-1972, Art. IV, § 463; Ord. 1986-1, passed 8-12-1986;
Ord. 1997-04, passed 3-18-1997)
§ 27-464 BASIC SPATIAL REGULATIONS.
   In this district, all buildings, structures and lots shall be subject to the
following basic spatial related regulations which shall be considered as
minimum standards:
   (A)   Lot requirements.
      (1)   Minimum area. Twenty thousand square feet; and
      (2)   Minimum width. One hundred feet.
   (B)   Setback requirements. Each lot shall have front, side and rear
setbacks of not less than the depth and width indicated below:
      (1)   Front setback. Minimum of 50 feet;
      (2)   Each side setback. Minimum of 50 feet, except when a residential
district is adjacent to the side setback, in which case the minimum side
setback shall be 100 feet;
      (3)   Mutual agreement. When a mutual agreement is subscribed by the
adjoining commercial property owners, no side setback shall be required where
