two commercial uses adjoin side by side; however, in no case shall common walls
be permitted between properties of separate ownership. In the case of such a
series of adjoining structures on lots of single and separate ownership
abutting and paralleling a public right-of-way, an unobstructed passage of at
least 20 feet in width shall be provided at grade level at intervals not more
than 400 feet apart; and
      (4)   Rear setback. Minimum of 50 feet, except when a residential
district is adjacent to the rear setback, in which case the minimum rear
setback shall be 100 feet.
   (C)   Maximum lot coverage and building height.
      (1)   Maximum building coverage. Forty percent; and
      (2)   Impervious coverage. No lot shall be covered by more than 80% with
impervious surface, including, but not limited to principal and accessory
buildings, driveways and walkways, and parking areas.
   (D)   Maximum building height. No building shall be extended to a height in
excess of 35 feet.
   (E)   Off-street parking and loading. Off-street parking, loading and
unloading areas shall be provided in accordance with the related regulations of
this chapter.
   (F)   Access and traffic control.
      (1)   No Planned Commercial District shall be permitted unless the main
entrance leads from a street, road or state route having a minimum 40 feet wide
cartway.
      (2)   All means of ingress or egress to any public street or state route
shall be located at least 200 feet from any other intersecting street or
streets and shall be designed to conduct traffic in a safe manner. The
developer shall be responsible for the purchase, erection and maintenance of
any necessary traffic control devices and the construction of additional
acceleration or deceleration lanes as may be required by the Pennsylvania
Department of Transportation or by the borough.
   (G)   Interior circulation. Interior access ways shall be designed so as to
prevent the blocking of vehicles entering or leaving the site. Areas provided
for loading or unloading of trucks and/or other vehicles or for servicing of
shops for rubbish collection or other services shall be adequate in size and
shall be so arranged that they may be used without blocking or interfering with
interior circulation and parking facilities.
   (H)   Channelization of vehicular movement.
      (1)   All parking areas which provide for more than 50 parking spaces
shall have raised landscaped islands at least five feet wide with curbs at the
ingress and egress of driveways from service drives and streets the full length
of a parking space to prevent encroachment of moving vehicles into parking
spaces.
      (2)   There shall be a raised landscaped island at each end of a row of
parking spaces. Such islands shall be the length of two parking spaces and at
least five feet in width.
      (3)   The edge of all paved areas shall have a continuous curb or stall
and blocks to prevent unsafe circulation of vehicles.
   (I)   Landscaping standards for channelization islands.
      (1)   All raised landscaped channelization islands and required setback
areas shall be landscaped with a mixture of grass, trees and shrubs, or other
materials to restrict blowing trash, retard water runoff, and deter improper
and unsafe access and site use by the public.
      (2)   All landscaping plant material shall be kept in excellent
condition. Dead plant material shall be replaced.
      (3)   Rock landscape areas shall be allowed.
      (4)   Trees, shrubs or flowers shall not be placed within 2 feet of a
curb to prevent damage of plant materials by auto bumpers.
   (J)   Lighting. Lighting for buildings, signs, access drives, and parking
areas shall be so arranged as not to reflect toward public streets or cause
annoyance to surrounding property owners or residents.
   (K)   Shopping cart storage. Establishments furnishing carts or mobile
baskets shall provide definite areas on the site for the storage of said carts.
Storage areas shall be clearly marked and designated for the storage of
shopping carts and/or mobile baskets.
   (L)   Screening.
      (1)   All property lines abutting residential districts, in the borough
or an adjoining municipality along the side yard or rear yard, shall be
appropriately screened by fences, walls, evergreen or other year-round planting
and/or other suitable enclosures of a minimum height of four feet and a maximum
height of five feet for walks and fences.
      (2)   If trees, evergreen hedges or other types of year-round plants are
used, landscaped areas shall be provided at least five feet in width along the
entire interior of the entire property line.
   (M)   Storage of trash or rubbish. Storage areas of trash and rubbish shall
be completely screened and all organic rubbish shall be contained in covered
vermin-proof containers. No such storage area shall be permitted within any
required yard space.
   (N)   Site plan review and approval. A proposed Planned Commercial Center
shall be subject to the provisions of the borough’s subdivision and land
development ordinance (Chapter 22 of this code of ordinances) and the
procedures established by said ordinance for approval of subdivision/land
development plans shall be followed in obtaining approval for any development
within the P-C District.
   (O)   Performance standards. All residential, commercial and industrial uses
shall comply with the performance standards set forth in § 27-509 of this
chapter. Residential performance standards deal with density and lot coverage
requirements, while commercial and industrial performance standards deal with
lot area and nuisance and hazard abatement requirements.
(Ord. 171, passed 1-18-1972, Art. IV, § 464; Ord. 1986-1, passed 8-12-1986;
Ord. 1997-04, passed 3-18-1997)
H: MU-C MIXED USE CENTER DISTRICT
Section
   
27-471   District purpose
   
27-472   Basic use regulations
   
27-473   Basic spatial regulations
   
27-474   Design regulations
§ 27-471 DISTRICT PURPOSE.
   To provide for the redevelopment of an underutilized area of the borough
into a sustainable mixed-use center which meet the goals and objectives and
concept plan set forth in the borough’s 1999 comprehensive plan amendment. The
objectives relate to the following goals: to protect and/or enhance the area;
to maximize the area’s land use potential; to provide the area with safe and
adequate access, an internal roadway network, and public sanitary sewer and
water; and to develop with a sensitivity to the area’s environmental elements.
(Ord. 171, passed 1-18-1972; Ord. 2000-1, passed 5-9-2000, § 3)
§ 27-472 BASIC USE REGULATIONS.
   In this district, buildings, structures and lots shall be subject to the
basic use regulations set forth in this section.
   (A)   Uses by right. The following uses are permitted by right in the MU-
C District:
      (1)   Residential uses:
         (a)   Single-family attached dwelling; and
         (b)   Multi-family dwelling.
      (2)   Recreational uses:
         (a)   Community center; and
         (b)   Neighborhood park/playground.
      (3)   Public/semi-public uses:
         (a)   Public/semi-public buildings or service structure;
         (b)   Public/semi-public utility building or service structure; and
         (c)   Public/semi-public parking lot or garage.
      (4)   Office/institutional uses:
         (a)   Business office;
         (b)   Contractor’s office or shop;
         (c)   Medical clinic;
         (d)   Professional office; and
         (e)   Professional/business office complex.
      (5)   Commercial uses:
         (a)   Adult or child day care;
         (b)   Artisan studio/galleries;
         (c)   Bed and breakfast inn;
         (d)   Country inn;
         (e)   Building supply establishment;
         (f)   Eating establishment, excluding drive-through service.
Restaurants with outdoor eating areas on sidewalks or courtyards shall meet the
following standards.
            1.   A minimum of five feet of sidewalk along the curb and leading
to the entrance to the establishment shall be maintained free of tables and
other encumbrances to allow for pedestrian circulation.
            2.   Planters, posts with ropes or other removable enclosures are
encouraged and shall be used as a way of defining the area occupied by the
eating establishment.
            3.   Extended awnings, canopies or large umbrellas shall be
permitted and located to provide shade in accordance with the following
standards. No awning or canopy shall extend more than 24 inches over the
sidewalk and shall have a height at its lowest point of at least eight feet ten
inches. Whenever a decorative canopy is to be constructed on any building,
which will not extend more than 36 inches beyond such building, such canopy
shall not be considered as part of the building for the purpose of determining
the depth of a front setback.
            4.   Outdoor eating establishments shall be required to provide
additional outdoor trash receptacles.
            5.   The operators of the outdoor eating establishments shall be
responsible for maintaining a clean, litter-free and well-kept appearance
within the immediate area of activities.
         (g)   Farmers market;
         (h)   Home occupations (accessory);
         (i)   Indoor commercial recreation establishment;
         (j)   Personal service business, excluding adult regulated facility;
         (k)   Retail store or shop;
         (l)   Small processing establishment;
         (m)   Specialty center, no use shall occupy more than 3,000 square
feet gross floor area;
         (n)   Tavern shall meet the following additional conditions.
            1.   The site shall be located a minimum of 150 feet from any
school, child or adult daycare facility, community or senior center, or church.
            2.   The proposed use shall not be detrimental to the neighborhood
due to hours of operation, light and/or litter.
            3.   The proposed use shall not constitute a nuisance to the
neighborhood due to noise or loitering outside the building.
            4.   No alcoholic beverages may be advertised on the exterior of
the building, including but not limited to banners, awnings, umbrellas or
lighted window signs.
         (o)   Wholesale establishment.
      (6)   Multi-use building uses:
         (a)   Commercial (first floor)/residential (upper floors);
         (b)   Commercial (first floor)/office (upper floors);
         (c)   Office (first floor)/residential (upper floors); and
         (d)   Existing buildings may be converted to multi-use buildings of
the types in subsections (A)(6)(a), (A)(6)(b) or (A)(6)(c) above.
      (7)   Accessory structures and uses associated with, but incidental to,
the above uses.
   (B)   Mix of uses. In order to maintain the character of the mixed-use area
and to avoid the site being dominated by one use the following mix of uses
shall be maintained.
      (1)   No more than 40% of the district’s total area shall be occupied by
residential uses.
      (2)   At least 50% of the residential uses shall be a part of a multi-use
structure.
      (3)   No more than 20% of the district’s total area shall be occupied by
single-use buildings occupying lots of one-half acre or more. Under no
circumstances shall a single-use building be allowed on a lot greater than one
acre unless the lot of a larger size existed on the effective date of this
chapter amendment.
(Ord. 171, passed 1-18-1972; Ord. 2000-1, passed 5-9-2000, § 3)
§ 27-473 BASIC SPATIAL REGULATIONS.
   In this district, all buildings, structures and lots shall be subject to the
following basic spatial related regulations, which shall be considered as
minimum standards.
   (A)   Lot area and bulk requirements. Lot area and bulk requirements shall
be provided for each principal use hereafter established for the MU-C District
in accordance with the area and bulk requirements table located at the end of
this chapter.
   (B)   Site development standards.
      (1)   Building facades shall be constructed and maintained parallel to
the curbline with the exception of passages for pedestrian access. Setbacks and
variations are addressed in the area and bulk regulations table.
      (2)   The street elevation of principal structures shall have at least
one street oriented entrance.
      (3)   Parking facilities shall be located in the rear or side yard. Under
no circumstances shall parking be located in the front yard.
      (4)   Sidewalk display of retail merchandise are permitted, provided
that:
         (a)   At least five feet of clearance is maintained at the storefront
entrance for adequate and uncluttered pedestrian access;
         (b)   The display is located against the building wall and does not
extend more than two feet into the sidewalk; and
         (c)   The display area does not exceed 75% of the length of the
storefront.
(Ord. 171, passed 1-18-1972; Ord. 2000-1, passed 5-9-2000, § 3)
§ 27-474 DESIGN REGULATIONS.
   In this district, all buildings, structures, and lots shall be subject to
the following basic design regulations.
   (A)   Streetscape plan.
      (1)   A streetscape plan developed by a registered landscape architect
shall be submitted with the submission of land development plans.
      (2)   The streetscape plan shall show and describe at a minimum the
location of street trees, sidewalks, lighting standards and landscaped areas.
      (3)   (a)   The streetscape plan shall assign responsibility for tree
maintenance, including watering, fertilizing, pruning, pest control and
monitoring for hazardous limbs.
         (b)   It shall be the responsibility of the property owner to maintain
all streetscapes outside of the public right-of-way.
   (B)   Sidewalks.
      (1)   Sidewalks shall be provided adjacent to all public streets and
constructed as shown in the mixed use center amenities specifications and shall
be a minimum of five feet in width.
      (2)   Sidewalks to be dedicated to the borough for public access shall be
contained within the public right-of-way.
   (C)   Lighting.
      (1)   Lighting in public areas shall meet the style and specifications as
shown in the mixed use center amenities specifications and in accordance with
the borough’s subdivision and land development ordinance (
Chapter 22 of this code of ordinances).
      (2)   Lighting in private areas shall be consistent in style with that
described for public areas. Pole-mounted lights in private areas shall not
exceed a total height of 18 feet from the finished grade to the top of
fixtures.
   (D)   Street trees.
      (1)   Street trees shall be planted within the street right-of-way in a
planting strip having a minimum width of five feet in accordance with mixed use
center amenities specifications.
      (2)   Trees shall be planted a maximum of 40 feet apart and in accordance
with the borough’s subdivision and land development ordinance (
Chapter 22 of this code of ordinances).
   (E)   Parking.
      (1)   Parking shall comply with §
27-507 of this chapter.
      (2)   The following additional standards shall apply to parking lots in
the MU-C District.
         (a)   Parking lots shall not be located closer than ten feet to a
public right-of-way.
         (b)   Parking lot layout, landscaping, buffering and screening shall
prevent direct views of parked vehicles from streets and sidewalks.
            1.   Parking lots shall be surrounded by a minimum three-foot high
(at maturity), year-round visually impervious screen, hedge or wall in
accordance with §
22-506(F)(3) of the borough’s subdivision and land development ordinance (
Chapter 22 of this code of ordinances).
            2.   If trees, evergreen or other year-round plants are used,
landscaped areas shall be provided at least five feet in width.
            3.   The height shall decrease where driveways approach sidewalks
or walkways, in order to provide adequate visibility of pedestrians from motor
vehicles and shall not interfere with clear sight triangle requirements.
         (c)   For parking lots over 20 spaces, at least 5% of the interior
parking area shall be landscaped with plantings and one tree of at least two
and one-half inch caliper at planting shall be provided for each ten spaces.
            1.   A mixture of hardy flowering and/or decorative evergreen and
deciduous trees may be planted.
            2.   Evergreens shall be used for screening the lot perimeter and
deciduous trees for shade within the lot in accordance with the borough’s
subdivision and land development ordinance (
Chapter 22 of this code of ordinances).
            3.   The area around the tree and under the overhang of vehicles
shall be mulched, planted with shrubs or ground cover, or covered with paving
materials.
         (d)   Parking lots shall contain clearly defined internal pedestrian
walkways linking the lot to the principal building on site and to the nearest
walkway.
         (e)   Shared parking lots are encouraged in accordance with §
27-507(A)(5). On-street parking in front of the use may be included in the
calculation of available spaces.
      (3)   The following standards shall apply to other parking facilities.
         (a)   On-street parking shall be allowed but only in a configuration
parallel to the curb.
         (b)   No automobile garage doors shall face directly onto a public
street, other than a secondary service street.
   (F)   Screening.
      (1)   All nonresidential, single-family attached dwelling or multi-family
dwelling uses abutting residential districts or single-family detached or semi-
detached dwelling uses shall be screened the entire length of the abutting
property line.
         (a)   Screening shall include fences, walls, evergreens or year-round
planting and/or other suitable enclosures of a minimum height of four feet for
vegetation and a maximum height of four feet for walls and fences.
         (b)   If trees, evergreen or other year-round plants are used,
landscaped areas shall be provided at least five feet in width.
      (2)   Storage of trash and utility areas shall be screened through a
minimum four feet tall, impervious wall, fence or landscaping.
   (G)   Greenways and drainage buffers.
      (1)   Greenways shall be utilized on lots to preserve existing woodlands
and drainage ways.
      (2)   The greenway shall connect with the adjoining lot to form a
greenways network within the district.
      (3)   Greenways shall be designed in accordance with the mixed use center
amenities specifications; under no circumstances shall greenways be less than
20 feet wide.
   (H)   Signage. The following design standards shall apply to signs in the
MU-C District and shall be supplemented by the standards found in this chapter.
      (1)   Sign may not be internally lit.
      (2)   The following permanent signs shall be allowed as described in
Chart A Permitted Permanent Signs and Chart B Permitted Temporary Signs of this
chapter and as allowed herein.
         (a)   Permanent signs: P-1, P-2, P-3, P-4, P-5, P-6 and P-7;
         (b)   Temporary sign: T-1, T-2, T-3, T-4, T-5, T-6, T-7, T-8A, T-8B
and T-9 and T-10;
         (c)   One freestanding business sign meeting the following standards:
            1.   The maximum area shall not exceed three square feet;
            2.   The minimum setback from the right-of-way shall be five feet;
            3.   The maximum height shall be seven feet; and
            4.   The sign shall be located within four feet of the main
entrance of the business and shall not interfere with pedestrian or vehicular
circulation.
         (d)   Attached business sign meeting the following standards:
            1.   The maximum projection from the building shall not exceed six
inches;
            2.   The area shall not exceed 5% of the ground floor building
facade area or 24 square feet, whichever is less;
            3.   The maximum height is 15 feet above the front sidewalk
elevation;
            4.   The sign shall be affixed to the front facade of the building;
and
            5.   Limit of one sign per business.
         (e)   One attached sign, not exceeding six square feet in area, shall
be permitted on any side or rear entrance open to the public.
         (f)   One attached building directory sign identifying the occupants
of a business establishment, including upper story business uses meeting the
following standards:
            1.   The sign is located next to the entrance;
            2.   The sign shall not project more than six inches from the
building; and
            3.   The area of the sign shall not exceed three square feet, with
each tenant limited to one square foot.
         (g)   One projecting sign per business but not in conjunction with any
of the aforementioned signs. The sign shall meet the following standards:
            1.   The sign shall not exceed an area of six square feet;
            2.   The height of the lower edge of the sign shall be eight feet
or greater;
            3.   The distance from the building wall to the sign shall not
exceed six inches; and
            4.   The width shall not exceed three feet.
         (h)   One painted window or door sign (not both) shall meet the
following standards and shall be in addition to one of the aforementioned
signs:
            1.   The sign shall not exceed 10% of the window or door area or
four square feet, whichever is less; and
            2.   The sign shall be silk screened or hand painted.
         (i)   One awning sign, for ground floor uses only, meeting the
following standards:
            1.   The area shall not exceed ten square feet when acting as the
main business sign and shall not be in addition to an attached sign; and
            2.   The area shall not exceed four square feet when acting as an
auxiliary business sign and shall be located on the valance only.
(Ord. 171, passed 1-18-1972; Ord. 2000-1, passed 5-9-2000)
